heading: Liverpool stars Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mane to face off in AFCON final
article_content:
Liverpool teammates 
and Sadio Mane will come face to face in the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) final after Egypt booked its place in Sundayâ€™s game. 
    

            
 was awaiting the winner of Thursdayâ€™s semifinal between Cameroon and Egypt and, despite the host having the better chances, it was the Pharaohs who progressed on penalties. 
    

            Egyptian goalkeeper Mohamed Abou Gabal produced two brilliant saves in the shootout before Cameroonâ€™s Clinton Njie fired his penalty wide of the post to send Egypt through after a goalless draw. 
    

            Egypt will now be bidding for a record-extending eighth AFCON title while Senegal looks to win its first. 
    

            Sundayâ€™s final will also be the first of three matches between the two sides in the coming months with the teams pitted against each other in a two-legged playoff for a place in this yearâ€™s World Cup in Qatar. 
    

            Both Salah and Mane have spearheaded Liverpoolâ€™s success in recent seasons and they now carry the hopes of their nations on their backs. 
    

            Neither have been in lightning form during this yearâ€™s tournament but both have still scored goals, Mane netting three times and Salah twice. 
    

            

    

            Senegal last reached an AFCON final in 2019, eventually losing 1-0 to Algeria, and the current crop of players will certainly be feeling the weight of expectation to finally end the countryâ€™s wait for a title. 
    

            The current team â€“ the top-ranked side on the continent â€“ is full of talented players, representing clubs such as Paris Saint-Germain, Chelsea, Liverpool and Bayern Munich.
    

            â€œExperience is a good asset,â€ Mane said. 
    

      
      

      

    

            â€œI think that has always been the case since the start of this tournament. We suffered so much with a lot of Covid cases and several injuries too.
    

            â€œWe had a very difficult time, but with our experience, we kept calm until we recovered the whole group.
    

            â€œWe played a final last time, so we have experience and we will try to win this trophy.â€
    

            Egypt, meanwhile, have surprised many by making it so far in the tournament and have scraped through games without producing much exciting football. 
    

            Perhaps crucially, Egypt will be without manager Carlos Queiroz on the sideline for the final after the former Manchester United assistant was sent off for arguing with the referee in Thursdayâ€™s match. 
    

            Queiroz has been pivotal in making this Egyptian side hard to beat but will now watch from behind the scenes as the country looks to make yet more history. 
    

            It will once again look to rely on Salah who has been one of the best players in the world this season. 
    

            â€œWe are happy, itâ€™s true, but we have not yet reached the final objective,â€ Egyptâ€™s assistant coach, Diaa Elsayed, said after the match. 
    

            â€œI can also add that our background is also due to the presence of one of the great players, namely Mohamed Salah. A very essential player in our team and who remains the centerpiece for us.â€
    

            Salah posted videos to his Instagram story of the Egyptian players celebrating their semifinal victory on the team bus, but he will be looking to go one further to establish himself further as a serial winner.

heading: Spanish judge imposes temporary ban on Uber taxi service
article_content:
A judge in Madrid temporarily halts Uber operations in Spain
Taxi drivers' association argues that Uber is unfair competition and lacks proper licenses
It is expected to file a formal complaint before the court; Uber can then make its case

            A Spanish judge on Tuesday temporarily banned cell phone-based taxi service Uber from operating in Spain after a complaint brought by taxi drivers in the capital, Madrid.
    

            The judge issued the ban, the equivalent of a temporary injunction, on the grounds that Uber was deemed to be causing damage to the taxi industry, a court spokesman said.
    

            The hearing was in response to a complaint by the Madrid taxi association, which argued that Uber is unfair competition and also lacks the proper municipal licenses to operate a taxi service.
    

            The Madrid taxi association is expected now to file a formal lawsuit with the court, after gathering more documents and information, the court spokesman said.
    

            Legal arguments for Uber were not heard before the judge because the company is located outside of Spain, in the U.S. state of Delaware, and the taxi industry was seeking immediate relief, he said.
    

            The company is expected to have a chance to argue its points before the judge when the formal lawsuit is filed.
    

            The Madrid ruling comes on the same day that 
 after an Uber driver was accused of raping a woman in New Delhi.
    

            Transport authorities in New Delhi on Monday 
, saying their investigation revealed the company was violating permit rules.
    

  CNNâ€™s Al Goodman reported from Madrid and Elwyn Lopez from Atlanta, while Laura Smith-Spark wrote in London.

heading: English Premier League players â€˜thrown under a PR busâ€™ by clubs, says Gary Lineker
article_content:
Adored by millions of fans around the world, 
 suddenly find themselves in an unusual position â€“ a lightning rod for criticism from both the public and politicians amid the coronavirus pandemic.
    

            Earlier this week, Tottenham Hotspur, Newcastle United, Norwich City and Bournemouth announced they would be using 
â€“  intended to aid those employers most severely affected by the Covid-19 shutdown â€“ to help pay the wages of non-playing members of staff placed on temporary leave.
    

            However, with the 20 Premier League clubs sharing the spoils of the current multi-billion dollar TV rights deal, many questioned why the players â€“ who earn on average Â£3 million ($3.7 million) per year â€“ werenâ€™t helping foot the bill.
    

            â€œI think everybody needs to play their part in this national effort and that means Premier League footballers too,â€ British Health Secretary Matt Hancock said during Thursdayâ€™s daily coronavirus briefing.
    

            â€œGiven the sacrifices people are making, including some of my colleagues in the NHS, who have made the ultimate sacrifice and gone into work and caught the disease and have sadly died, I think the first thing Premier League footballers can do is make a contribution; take a pay cut and play their part.â€
    

            

    

            The Professional Footballers Association (PFA) â€“ the playersâ€™ union in England â€“ has been holding talks with the Premier League and the English Football League (EFL) over soccerâ€™s response to Covid-19 and one former leading player Gary Lineker, who now works as a TV pundit, told CNN that the football stars were convenient scapegoats for politicians.
    

            â€œWe do tend to have a go at footballers quite easily,â€ former England international Gary Lineker told Richard Quest. â€œTheyâ€™re easy game. Yes, they get paid a lot of money, but Iâ€™m sure they want to help. 
    

            â€œTheyâ€™re consistently very good in the communities and Iâ€™m sure over the coming days that footballers will stand up and be counted, either taking pay cuts or making donations to charities or staff workers that are non-playing. 
    

            â€œSo, Iâ€™m confident that will happen, but it takes time and everyone here is jumping on the bandwagon. Politicians do tend to do that occasionally, especially at footballâ€™s expense â€“ so, if Iâ€™m wrong, then Iâ€™ll be as critical as everybody else.â€
    

            In a statement released on Friday, the Premier League said it planned to start a consultation exercise with top-flight players.
    

            â€œIn the face of substantial and continuing losses for the 2019/20 season since the suspension of matches began, and to protect employment throughout the professional game, Premier League clubs unanimously agreed to consult their players regarding a combination of conditional reductions and deferrals amounting to 30% of total annual remuneration.
    

            â€œThe League will be in regular contact with the PFA, and the union will join a meeting which will be held tomorrow [April 4] between the League, players and club representatives.â€
    

            

    

            This week, Barcelona and Atletico Madrid players took a 70% wage cut to ensure that all non-playing members of staff continue to get paid a full salary during the pandemic, while Juventusâ€™ first-team squad has given up 100% of its wages for four months to save the club $100 million.
    

            â€œI think one or two of our clubs have kind of thrown their players under a PR bus in many ways by announcing that theyâ€™re cutting staff salaries and putting them on furlough, but not affecting the playersâ€™ wages,â€ said Lineker.
    

            â€œThat was not announced by the players, but it was announced by the clubs, so letâ€™s wait and see. Letâ€™s be a little bit patient here. Letâ€™s not all jump on the judgment high horse and just wait and see how it pans out over the next week or so. 
    

            â€œIâ€™m confident and I would be very disappointed if the players donâ€™t do the right thing, but Iâ€™m sure they will.â€
    

            

    

            The PFA called an urgent meeting on March 27 with the Premier League and the EFL to ensure the salaries of footballers in the third and fourth tiers â€“ whose wages, it says, are â€œcloser to the national averageâ€ â€“ were protected for April.
    

            â€œMany of these players will have contracts ending in June,â€ the PFA said in a statement on Thursday. â€œThese are often people with young families, for whom their immediate financial position is uncertain.â€
    

            While TV money has funded handsome salaries for many players, itâ€™s arguably also benefited the super-rich owners of the 20 Premier League clubs, whose combined wealth totals close to $85 billion, according to Forbes.
    

            Which is why the the PFA says that while it is aware of the publicâ€™s belief that players should give up their salaries to pay the wages of non-playing members of staff, it reiterated its stance that if clubs can afford to pay both, then they should continue to do so.
    

            â€œThe players we have spoken to recognize that the non-playing staff are a vital part of their club and they do not want to see club staff furloughed unfairly,â€ it said. â€œAny use of the governmentâ€™s support schemes without genuine financial need is detrimental to the wider society. 
    

            â€œIn instances where clubs have the resources to pay all staff, the benefit of players paying non-playing staff salaries will only serve the business of the clubâ€™s shareholders.â€

heading: Welsh football team equals Ajaxâ€™s 44-year-old world record
article_content:
Welsh side has won 26 consecutive matches 
Ajax set record in 1971-72 season 
The New Saints can break it on Dec 30

            Chelsea may be grabbing all the headlines with its impressive 12-match winning streak in the English Premier League, but thatâ€™s nothing compared to a team across the border in Wales.
    

            The New Saints FC notched a 26th consecutive win in the Welsh Premier League on Monday to equal the world record by set Dutch giant Ajax during 1971-72 Eredivisie season. 
    

            The four-time European champion tweeted its congratulations to the Welsh side, which cruised to a 4-0 victory over Cefn Druids in front of a home crowd. 
    
great achievement guys! Happy Boxing Day! ğŸ‘Š

            â€œItâ€™s been a bit of a shock that weâ€™ve got to this stage,â€ club chairman Mike Harris told CNNâ€™s World Sport show Tuesday.  
    

            â€œWeâ€™d recognized that weâ€™d got to the longest run of games in our league a few weeks ago when we passed the Bangor City total, but we still thought we had a bit of a way to go.â€
    

            Harris and the club were only made aware of the feat when the Guinness Book of Records got in touch before the crucial match on Boxing Day.   
    

            

    

            â€œThat got everyone a little bit on edge, but obviously the game went in our favor so we managed to get over that last hurdle,â€ Harris said. 
    

            â€œI think the players are a great set of players and youâ€™ve also got to give great testimony to our manager Craig Harrison, who is very professional in the way that he treats every single game, every training session and in his selection of players heâ€™s put together over the last few years.â€ 
    

            Harrisonâ€™s team has emulated an Ajax side that, featuring the great Johan Cruyff, went on to complete the treble in 1972 by winning the Eredivisie, the Dutch Cup and the European Cup â€“ the precursor to todayâ€™s Champions League. 
    

            TNS, by comparison, has never made it past the qualifying rounds of the continentâ€™s top club competition in 10 attempts.
    

      
      

      

    

            Now 21 points clear at the top of the 12-team Welsh Premier League, the team can break the world record when it plays second-bottom Cefn Druids again on Friday. 
    

            

    

            â€œThereâ€™s a lot of hard work going on in the Welsh Premier League,â€ said Harris, whose team has won the title for the past five seasons. 
    

            â€œItâ€™s a very young league compared to the more established leagues in Europe, but the clubs have worked really, really hard over the last 20 years to keep pushing forward. 
    

            

    

            â€œItâ€™s nice to get some recognition for all the hard work thatâ€™s gone on over that time.â€

heading: Andy Murray withdraws from Citi Open after grueling 3 a.m. victory
article_content:
Murray says he is exhausted after two three-set encounters in two days
The former No. 1 is returning from hip injury

            An emotional Andy Murray sobbed into his towel on the side of the court after a grueling victory over world No. 93 Marius Copil in Washington â€“ a game that finished at 3 a.m. Friday local time.
    

            Hours later, tournament organizers confirmed
 that Murray had withdrawn from Washingtonâ€™s Citi Open due to fatigue and would not play in the quarterfinals. He also will not compete in the Rogers Cup next week in Toronto, they said.
    

            â€œIâ€™m exhausted after playing so much over the past four days, having not competed on the hard courts for 18 months,â€ Murray said in a statement. â€œI also need to be careful and to listen to my body as I come from a long-term injury.â€
    

            Murray, who continues his return from hip surgery, overcame the Romanian 6-7 6-3 7-6 in his second three-set encounter in two days, having previously defeated fellow Briton Kyle Edmund. 
    
No words, 
. 
Just thanks for your emotions... ğŸ˜ğŸ™
 

            â€œJust the emotions coming at the end of an extremely long day and a long match,â€ Murray, 31, said of his reaction to the Copil match, after which he sat crying into his towel for several minutes. 
    

            The former world No. 1 had to dig deep after conceding a 5-0 advantage in the first-set tie break to lose 7-5, but Murray twice broke Copil in the second set to force a decider.
    

            

    

            The pair shared breaks in the third set, and as the clock ticked on later into the night, Murray eventually emerged victorious (7-4) in the final tie break â€“ at 3:01 a.m.
    

            The three-time grand slam winner has slipped to world No. 832 during his injury rehab and is now chasing his first ATP title since March 2017. 
    

            

    

            Murray would have faced Alex de Minaur in the quarterfinals in Washington. The Australian defeated South Koreaâ€™s Hyeon Chung 6-2 4-6 6-2.

heading: Sevilla goalkeeper Marko DmitroviÄ‡ punched by pitch invader during Europa League match at PSV Eindhoven
article_content:
Sevillaâ€™s 2-0 loss to PSV Eindhoven in Thursdayâ€™s 
 match turned ugly when a pitch invader ran on the field and punched the Spanish clubâ€™s goalkeeper Marko DmitroviÄ‡ at the Philips Stadium in Eindhoven, the Netherlands.
    

            Towards the end of the match, which resulted in PSV being eliminated from the tournament 3-2 on aggregate, the spectator can be seen on video walking up to DmitroviÄ‡ before throwing a punch at his head.
    

      
      

      

    

            The 6-foot-4-inch Serbian goalkeeper quickly pinned down the pitch invader before security personnel arrived and escorted the assailant off the field.
    

            DmitroviÄ‡, who made the start in goal after starter 
 was scratched late due to illness, stayed in the game after the incident.
    

            â€œHe pushed me from behind and then came and got in my face and tried to hit me,â€ DmitroviÄ‡ said of the incident. 
    

            â€œHe grazed the side of my nose a little and then honestly, I wanted to hit him back but itâ€™s never pretty. If he really wants to fight letâ€™s go to an event or a sport like boxing or anything. Here, in this sport, these things arenâ€™t deserved but alas.
    

      
      

      

    

            â€œThereâ€™s always fans who are drunk and crazy and an idiot who assaults. This shouldnâ€™t happen and I hope they punish him and anyone else who assaults anyone on the pitch in the future.â€
    

            Six-time champion Sevilla cruised past PSV Eindhoven 3-0 in the first leg of the playoff, leaving the Dutch side with a tall task heading into Thursday nightâ€™s match.
    

            In the second leg, Luuk de Jong netted a goal in the 77th minute for PSV Eindhoven. 
    

            After the DmitroviÄ‡ incident, substitute Fabio Silva doubled PSVâ€™s lead five minutes into stoppage time but it was too little, too late as the full-time whistle would be blown shortly after.
    

            Despite the second-leg loss, Sevilla advances to the Round of 16.

heading: Chris Froomeâ€™s bike â€˜totaledâ€™ by hit-and-run driver
article_content:
Froome rammed by motorist while out riding his bike 
Three-time Tour de France winner says bike is "totaled"
Froome was training near his home in Monaco

            Three-time Tour de France winner Chris Froome has been knocked off his bike in a hit-and-run incident while training near Monaco.
    

            The British cyclist, who won the Tour in 2013, 2015 and 2016, tweeted a picture of his crumpled bike on Tuesday but confirmed he hadnâ€™t been injured.
    

            He said: â€œJust got rammed on purpose by an impatient driver who followed me onto the pavement! Thankfully Iâ€™m okay. Bike totaled. Driver kept going!â€
    
Just got rammed on purpose by an impatient driver who followed me onto the pavement! Thankfully I'm okay ğŸ™ Bike totaled. Driver kept going! 

            The Briton was riding in Beausoleil, close to his home in Monaco, when the incident took place. He is currently in training ahead of the CritÃ©rium du DauphinÃ©, an eight-day race in southern France that starts on June 4.
    

            

    

            

    

            The CritÃ©rium du DauphinÃ© forms part of the Kenyan-born cyclistâ€™s preparations for his attempt to win a hat-trick of Tour de France titles, when the worldâ€™s most prestigious road race returns for its 104th edition.
    

            Italian cyclist and 2011 Giro dâ€™Italia winner Michele Scarponi was killed in April when he was hit by a van when out on a training ride near his home in Filottrano, on the east coast.
    

            â€œThis is a tragedy too big to be written,â€ his team Astana said in a statement about Scarponi, who had two young children with his wife Anna.
    

      
      

      

    

            Froome is a divisive figure in France.
    

            With the 
 still hanging over the Tour, Froome has been repeatedly accused of doping even though he insists he has always raced clean.
    

            He has been shouted at and spat on during the race, with one fan even throwing a cup of urine over him during the 2015 installment and calling him a doper.
    

            In an eventful race last year, Froome was fined for lashing out at a spectator who ran too close to him and decided to briefly jog up the famous Mont Ventoux after a crash wiped out his bike.
    

            The 31-year-old Froome says he sees himself as a spokesman for clean cycling and insists the recent controversy surrounding Team Sky will not affect his legacy.
    

            His team has been rocked by a UK Anti-Doping inquiry after revelations that a mystery package was delivered to Bradley Wiggins at an event shortly before his 2011 Tour win.
    

            Team Sky boss Dave Brailsford appeared before a Parliament select committee to reveal the decongestant Fluimucil was in the package bound for Wiggins. 
    

            Questions have also been asked about how Team Sky used therapeutic use exemptions (TUEs), which are essentially doctorâ€™s notes enabling athletes to use medicines that would otherwise be banned.
    

            Wiggins has come under particular scrutiny over his use of TUEs for the banned anti-inflammatory drug triamcinolone as well as that package that was delivered by British Cycling coach Simon Cope during the 2011 Criterium du Dauphine tour.
    

            Wiggins has yet to publicly comment on the UKAD inquiry though in March he told Sky Sportsâ€™ Soccer AM show: â€œFortunately thereâ€™s an investigation and I obviously canâ€™t say too much because that will run its course and then Iâ€™ll have my say.
    

            â€œThereâ€™s a lot to say and itâ€™s going to shock a few people.â€ 
    

            

    

            Team Sky have constantly maintained that while they may have handled the situation badly, nothing untoward took place.

heading: Nine years of austerity have stripped thousands of disabled Brits of support they need to survive
article_content:
Sarifa Patelâ€™s 500-foot trip to her nearest bus stop takes half an hour. Walking is painful and she needs several breaks. Patel, who lives in east London, has a wheelchair, but since undergoing surgery a few years ago she no longer has the strength to push herself.
    

            The 60-year-old doesnâ€™t want to give up her part-time job at a charity, so requested a mobility scooter through a government scheme aimed at helping disabled people access employment. She has been waiting for three years.
    

            A decade of austerity policies and deep cuts to social services and 
 in the United Kingdom has made it difficult for people like Patel to access the care they need. A 2018 report by a UN human rights expert said government policy has â€œ
 â€¦ on people with disabilities who are already marginalized.â€
    

            The future is also uncertain. New UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson has pledged more money for the cash-strapped National Health Service. Johnsonâ€™s hardline approach to Brexit, however, increases the likelihood of the country leaving the European Union without a deal, with potentially damaging economic consequences 
    

            According to forecasts by the 
 and the 
, a no-deal Brexit would likely push the UK into a deep recession and put public spending under pressure. It was the last recession, sparked by the global financial crisis in 2008, that led to the austerity measures that the UN says have decimated Britainâ€™s social services.

    

            For Patel, the situation is difficult now. She 
, a long-term condition that causes pain, muscle spasms and stiffness. Sometimes it is so bad she canâ€™t walk at all. 
    

            â€œIâ€™ve been really struggling with my knees, but theyâ€™ve not listened to me,â€ she says of her scooter request.
    

            The UK governmentâ€™s Department of Work and Pensions (DWP), which is responsible for disability benefits, would not comment on Patelâ€™s individual case.
    

      
      

      

    

            If Patel really needs to go somewhere, her only option is to take a cab. Patel spends roughly Â£200 ($242) a month on taxis. Itâ€™s money she says she wouldnâ€™t have to spend if she wasnâ€™t disabled.
    

            Thatâ€™s a common story. Scope, a UK disability charity, said the average â€œdisability price tagâ€ comes to Â£583 ($706) a month. 
    

            â€œThatâ€™s the amount disabled people have to spend on things that non-disabled people donâ€™t need,â€ James Taylor, Scopeâ€™s head of policy, told CNN.
    

            This figure includes buying and repairing special equipment, as well as spending money on everyday goods and services that disabled people have to use a lot more often, Taylor said. 
    

            The extra cost has grown in recent years. Following the global economic crisis, successive UK governments attempted to save money by reforming Britainâ€™s welfare system. 
    

            These changes were meant to make the system leaner and more streamlined, replacing â€œoutdatedâ€ benefits with new ones. But the reform proved difficult for many people living with disabilities.
    

            â€œIt was designed as more cost-effective and less generous,â€ Taylor said. 
    

            â€œWe are finding people who were getting the previous benefit are no longer able to get the new one, so there is a group of disabled people who have been hit very hard,â€ he added.
    

            Latest available DWP 
 show that as of last October, 47% of people who were receiving the old disability benefit, known as Disability Living Allowance, had their payments reduced or scrapped altogether after transferring to the new system, called Personal Independence Payment.
    

            That is intentional: the government expected the reform would mean around 
.
    

      
      

      

    

            It said that the point was to make the system more sustainable and focused on those with the greatest needs.
    

            A DWP spokesperson said the new system is better because it is â€œtaking a much wider look at the way a personâ€™s health condition or disability impacts them on a daily basis.â€ 
    

            But Scope said some disabled people have lost Â£300 to Â£400 a month because of the changes. â€œThat has a huge impact on what theyâ€™re able to afford, and the quality of life that they have,â€ Taylor said. 
    

            Most people switching to the new system have to go through an official assessment to determine the level of care and mobility assistance they need. 
    

            The requirements became stricter under the new system. For example, it used to be that anyone unable to walk 50 meters (164 feet) without aid would qualify for higher mobility support payments.
    

            Under the new system, only people who canâ€™t 
. That means that those who can walk over 20 meters but not 50 have suddenly had their payments slashed, even though their condition has not changed.
    

            A DWP spokesperson said the rule was not set in stone and that even people who can walk more than 20 meters can still get the higher rate if they â€œcannot do so safely, to an acceptable standard, repeatedly or in a reasonable time period.â€
    

            Patel was â€œdowngradedâ€ in 2016. She slumped from â€œhigherâ€ to â€œstandardâ€ support rates, resulting in more than Â£60 cut to her weekly payments. 
    

            â€œAnd then when I spoke to the wheelchair services people, they said I should be able to buy a scooter from the mobility benefit,â€ Patel said. She said a scooter or electric chair 
. Even if she was able to put money aside, it would take her years to save up enough to buy one. 
    

            She has tried to have the decision to lower her payments overturned and got a new assessment from a different doctor. She is now waiting for a tribunal.
    

      
      

      

    

            The tribunal odds are on Patelâ€™s side. According to the Ministry of Justice, 
 against disability payments decisions are successful.
But the appeal process is time consuming, taking on average almost a year. In the meantime, the person appealing is stuck without funds. 
    

            â€œIt inflicts hardship on people, because in many cases, most or a large portion of their income is withdrawn,â€ said Sara Reis, research and policy officer at the UK Womenâ€™s Budget Group, a research organization. 
    

            â€œAnd there will be many people who wonâ€™t go through the appeal process because itâ€™s an onerous thing and it can be daunting, intimidating to stand before a tribunal and state your case,â€ she added.
    

            While she awaits that decision, Patel hopes that when her next big muscle spasm comes, she wonâ€™t be out and about. Freezing up in the street makes her feel vulnerable. 
    

            â€œI get really frustrated and angry because I can be walkingâ€¦ and the next minute, my muscle spasms up in my leg, and it becomes like a pencilâ€¦ itâ€™s frightening.â€

heading: Never â€˜insult Poles again,â€™ Polandâ€™s prime minister tells Ukraineâ€™s Zelensky
article_content:
Polandâ€™s Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki has told Volodymyr Zelensky never to â€œinsult Poles againâ€ after the 
 president suggested his neighbor was putting on a show over their disputes on grain exports.
    

            The Polish leader fired back at Zelensky after the Ukrainian leader offered a veiled criticism of Poland at the United Nationsâ€™ general assembly this week, saying the dispute was â€œpolitical theaterâ€ and that â€œsome of our friends in Europeâ€ have â€œmade a thriller from the grain.â€
    

            On Friday, at a rally in Swidnik, Poland, Morawiecki hit back.
    

            â€œI want to tell President Zelensky never to insult Poles again, as he did recently during his speech at the UN,â€ he said.
    

            â€œThe Polish people will never allow this to happen, and defending the good name of Poland is not only my duty and honor, but also the most important task of the Polish government,â€ the Polish prime minister added.
    

      
      

      

    

            The comments by Morawiecki risk deepening the divisions between two countries that have previously been close allies united against Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.
    

            Tensions between them have been rising in recent weeks over a ban on Ukrainian grain, initially put in place earlier this year by several EU nations to protect the livelihood of local farmers worried about being undercut by the low price of Ukrainian grain.
    

            The EU announced plans to suspend the ban last week but 
 â€“ alongside Hungary and Slovakia â€“ said it would stick with it, sparking protests from Ukraine, which filed lawsuits against the three countries, and, subsequently, Zelenskyâ€™s comments at the UN.
    

            Poland immediately condemned Zelenskyâ€™s comments at the UN and its foreign ministry summoned the Ukrainian ambassador to convey its â€œstrong protest.â€ Hours later, the Polish prime minister said in a blunt social media statement that the country would â€œno longer transfer weapons to Ukraine because we are now arming Poland.â€
    

            That had seemed to indicate a major change in policy: until now, Poland has been one of the most forthright countries in the race to get weapons and resources into Ukrainian hands.
    

            But Polish President Andrzej Duda on Thursday moved to walk back his prime ministerâ€™s comments, saying they were â€œinterpreted in the worst possible way.â€
    

            He said Morawiecki had merely been referring to new weapons being purchased for the Polish army, and that older weapons systems Warsaw deems not necessary for modernizing its own military could still be shipped across the border.
    

            NATO and European sources 
 that the Polish stance may be an attempt to woo farmers with elections due next month. 
    

            Poland has long been one of Ukraineâ€™s staunchest allies, alongside multiple former Eastern bloc nations which fear they could be next if Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s expansionist war is successful.
    

            In another sign of disenchantment over Ukraine in Eastern Europe, Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto has said new sanctions against Russia are not needed because they â€œcause more harm to Europe than Russia.â€
    

            Szijjarto made the comments in an interview with Russian state media TASS on Friday following his meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly in New York. 
    

            â€œIf we look at the sanctions from a pragmatic point of view, we see that they cause more harm to Europe than to Russia,â€ he said, according to TASS, adding that â€œthe new packages of sanctions are not necessary.â€ 
    

            Szijjarto also said that supplies of Ukrainian grain to Central European countries will destroy their agricultural sector. 
    

            â€œIf Ukrainian grain starts to spread into Central European countries, it will definitely destroy the agricultural markets of Central Europe. Not to mention our farmers, whom we obviously need to protect,â€ Szijjarto continued, as cited by TASS.

heading: Step inside the kitchen of an F1 masterchef
article_content:
Michael Caines fueling F1 drivers
Award-winning chef works for Williams F1

            When Michael Caines lost his right arm in a car accident in 1994, the dream of becoming a top-level chef seemed a million miles away.
    

            Twenty-three years and two Michelin stars later, he hasnâ€™t just become one of his industryâ€™s most distinguished figures, heâ€™s also fueling some of the fastest drivers in the world.
    

            A partner and ambassador for Formula One team Williams Martini Racing, the 48-year-old hosts the teamâ€™s sponsors, engineers and drivers on race weekends. 
    

            â€œI grew up watching Williams dominate in that era of Nigel Mansell and Damon Hill being made World Champions for this great racing team,â€ says Caines, who has built an empire of 
 in the United Kingdom.
    

            â€œYou see your heroes on TV and think â€˜wow!â€™ â€¦ and the next thing you know, you find yourself in the paddock. 
    

            â€œIt is one of those pinch-yourself momentsâ€
    

            F1 has a relentless race calendar which runs from March to November and stops in 20 major cities. But from Australia to Abu Dhabi, the Brit shows itâ€™s possible to produce top-quality cuisine on the move. 
    

            â€œThey say an army marches on its stomach and Williams is no exception,â€ Caines tells CNN The Circuit. 
    

            â€œWeâ€™ve got to produce nutritious and healthy food for the drivers, but weâ€™ve also got to provide for the sponsors over the F1 weekend.â€ 
    

            His team designed a purpose-built motorhome four years ago to deliver a bespoke product for the Williams team and its numerous guests.  
    

            It can be quickly assembled at any location on the F1 circuit to deliver the optimum culinary experience, with a ground floor brasserie and first floor Michael Caines Tasting Experience.
    

            It might not be perfect, but as the chef puts it: â€œWe get pretty close to what I do in my restaurants here on the track!â€
    
Want to see what happens in the Williams Martini Racing kitchen? Williams TV takes you behind the scenes with 
 in Monaco. 

            

    

            Caines stresses the importance of a good diet for drivers, especially since this yearâ€™s new rulings have made the sport even more physically demanding. 
    

            Even if Williams drivers Felipe Massa and Lance Stroll probably wonâ€™t be troubling the top of the driversâ€™ standings at the end of this season, thereâ€™s little doubt the British team is well catered for especially, says Caines, when compared with what their rivals offer. 
    

            â€œThereâ€™s no competition!â€ laughs Caines. â€œWe out-qualify all of them!â€
    

            â€œToto Wolff will tell you. The first thing he said when he went to Mercedes was â€˜we want our hospitality to be just like Williamsâ€™.â€
    

            

    

            Not that Massa and Stroll are devouring
 before races. 
    

            Because drivers are out on the road so much, the most important ingredient is a taste of home.
    

            Both eat at a particular time on race weekends â€“ â€œwritten in as part of the dayâ€ â€“ and tend to not change their diet. 
    

            Stroll, an F1 debutant of Canadian descent, typically eats quinoa and high protein fish, like salmon or cod. 
    

            Massa, the first Brazilian since Ayrton Senna to win his home Grand Prix, rarely deviates from a dish of roast chicken, wild rice and tomato salad.
    

            â€œEveryone has to be made to feel welcome,â€ says Caines. â€œWhen theyâ€™re not having to worry about racing, theyâ€™ll also indulge off the menu!â€
    

            

    

            The chef admits sponsors are â€œso key to survivalâ€ for todayâ€™s F1 teams.
    

            Itâ€™s a fact Williams has embraced, going through 2,000 bottles of Prosecco over the course of the 2016 season.
    

            â€œIf results arenâ€™t always what they should be on the track, at least through hospitality you can give the sponsors a great experience throughout the race weekend,â€ says Caines. 
    

            â€œIâ€™m always thinking about how we can bring in different themes to different grands prix, whether thatâ€™s the cocktails or the food. 
    

            â€œWe always try to influence that with the wine choices as well â€“ English wines going alongside some of the dishes too.â€
    

            The opportunity to experiment is offset by the difficulty obtaining ingredients in some race locations. 
    

            He praises the produce on offer in Monaco, lauding â€œthe fantastic larder of fantastic seafood and salads,â€ but adds it can be slightly more challenging cooking in the likes of Russia and Hungary. 
    

            Still, with opportunity to watch races in between his cooking, Caines is in no doubt as to just how lucky he is. 
    

            â€œI derive a lot of satisfaction from the fact that something I loved as a kid is something Iâ€™m now in touch with,â€ he smiles. 
    

            

    

            â€œItâ€™s a team sport and it goes without saying that everyone involved with Williams is here to support the team to go on, race and hopefully win.â€

heading: Baby gorilla hand-reared by zookeepers after mother struggles to look after him
article_content:
Zookeepers in the British city of Bristol
are giving a baby 
 round-the-clock care, including bottle feeding through the night, as his mother has been struggling to look after him.
    

            The team of keepers at Bristol Zoo Gardens said
that the baby, now two months old but still unnamed, was not getting enough milk from his mother, Kala, to survive and would now be hand-reared for the next four months.
    

            â€œHand-rearing any animal is not a decision we take lightly as our preference is always for an animal to be reared naturally by its own mother,â€ Lynsey Bugg, mammals curator at the zoo, said in a statement. 
    

            â€œSadly, this doesnâ€™t always happen and in this instance we decided that it was in the baby gorillaâ€™s best interests for us to hand rear him to ensure he had the best chance of survival.â€ 
    

            Kala, the babyâ€™s mother, is said to be adjusting well and is in good health. 
    

            Bugg said that when the infant is away from his mother at night in onsite accommodation, zookeepers will try to treat him like his gorilla mother would, expecting him to hold on tight to them and making gorilla vocalizations.
    

            During the day, the infant will be in the zooâ€™s Gorilla House. It is hoped that if the animals are able to see, smell, touch, and be near him, the infant will soon be able to bond with the group and be accepted as a part of the family, the statement said.
    

            Zookeepers are keeping the baby gorilla out of public view for now, but visitors can view the rest of the group.
    

            The zoo invited members of the public to help choose a name 
. The options are: Motuku, meaning â€œChief of the Villageâ€ in Bubi, a local language in Equatorial Guinea; Hasani, meaning â€œhandsomeâ€ in Swahili; Luango, a town on the coast of Equatorial Guinea; or Kidosi, popular Central African name.

heading: German prosecutor accuses Russia of ordering murder in Berlin park
article_content:
Germanyâ€™s top prosecutor has accused 
 of ordering the murder of a Georgian man in a Berlin park, as they announced that a suspected contract killer has been charged over the killing. 
    

            The victim was a 40-year-old Georgian citizen of 
 descent named by German officials as Tornike K. He was shot dead by a man on a bicycle in downtown Berlinâ€™s Kleiner Tiergarten park on August 23, 2019. Previously named as 
, the former Chechen fighter had been on his way to midday prayers.
    

            A Russian national was arrested within hours over the killing, setting off a murder mystery that has gripped Germany.
    

            While the Kremlin has denied any connection between the murder and the Russian state, the shooting triggered an investigation which also raised uncomfortable questions about the relationship between the two countries.
    

      
      

      

    

            Germanyâ€™s federal prosecutor took over the investigation in December. On Thursday, almost ten months after the murder, they said they had gathered sufficient evidence and brought charges against the suspect.
    

            â€œAt an unknown date before July 18, 2019, the accused received the order from authorities at the central government of the Russian Federation to liquidate the Georgian national of Chechen origin,â€ the prosecutorâ€™s statement reads.
    

            The suspect, named as Vladim K., is accused of the murder and of illegal possession of a weapon, the statement added.
    

            â€œThe indictment by the federal prosecutor contains serious accusations regarding the involvement of Russian state authorities in the so-called Tiergarten murder case,â€ a German government spokesperson said Thursday, adding: â€œThe Federal Government takes this very seriously.â€
    

            The spokesperson said the German government would â€œcarefully monitorâ€ the rest of the trial until a verdict was reached, adding that two members of the Russian embassy were expelled in December in connection to the case, and that recently Germany had taken steps against Russia in connection with the hacking attack on the German Bundestag in 2015. 
    

            â€œThe German government reserves the right to take further steps,â€ the statement concluded.
    

  Nadine Schmidt reported from Berlin, Zamira Rahim wrote in London.

heading: Victims thought they were paying millions to free hostages. But the â€˜ministerâ€™ who asked them was a fraudster in a mask
article_content:
There was a sense of urgency in the voice of the man claiming to be 
 defense minister, Jean-Yves Le Drian.
    

             â€œWeâ€™re talking about the lives of 
 citizens and we would like to free them. If we donâ€™t, we expect the worst,â€ the man said in an audio recording of a telephone solicitation obtained by CNN. 
    

            â€œI need to know if you can join us in this mission so we can carry it out and if the answer is â€˜yesâ€™ then I will alert the presidency to say we have someone who can act as a mediator for us.â€ 
    

            On the receiving end of the telephone line was Olivier de Boisset, a Frenchman who heads an IT company in Niger.
    

            De Boisset was being asked to wire over 2 million dollars to allegedly help free French hostages being held by terrorists in Mali.
    

            The voice said France needed de Boissetâ€™s help transferring funds because officially the country does not pay ransoms and gave assurances that Franceâ€™s central bank would reimburse him.
    

            De Boisset was suspicious, but he could never have imagined the extent of the scam that was being played on him.
    

            Not only were there no French hostages in Mali, but he had just become the latest victim in a multi-million dollar con that would span two years and target more than 150 people including the spiritual leader Aga Khan, the President of Niger, the Prime Minister of Norway, the Archbishop of Lyon, the owner of Chateau Margaux wines, the King of Belgium, the director general of UNESCO and numerous CEOs.
    

            Attempts to extort money from embassies and governments were made in more than 50 countries, according to French court documents.
    

            CNN has obtained exclusive recordings made by often-skeptical victims showing how a group of fraudsters tried to pull off what some in France are calling the scam of the century by impersonating Franceâ€™s then defense minister, Jean-Yves Le Drian, and conning wealthy individuals out of 80 million euros purportedly to help pay ransoms to free French hostages being held by Islamist terrorists.
    

            Some of the money has not been recovered.
    

            Six of the alleged fraudsters are currently on trial in Paris in connection with the Le Drian hoax and a plot to impersonate Prince Albert II of Monaco while a seventh defendant is on trial only for the Albert of Monaco plot. 
    

            According to many of the victims, to earn their trust an initial phone call was followed up by a Skype video call. During this exchange, the con artist wore a custom-made silicone mask of Le Drianâ€™s face and sat in a replica of the ministerâ€™s office complete with both the tricolor flag of France and a flag of Europe, pictures in the court documents show.
    

            Another one of those targeted in June 2016 by the bogus Le Drian was Bruno Paillard, who heads a champagne house in Reims, northern France.
    

            Paillard told CNN the hustle was impressive because of its elaborate nature. â€œThe image was not very precise and the voice was a little bit strange. The excuse was that they were in a bunker in the ministry,â€ Paillard said.
    

            In addition to the Skype calls, Paillard said they communicated with him on official-looking letterheads from the ministry, but despite all their efforts Paillard said he wasnâ€™t convinced and went straight to the police. 
    

            â€œAs a champagne producer we make people happy, but weâ€™re not necessarily good at saving the lives of people who are being held in strange countries,â€ Paillard told CNN.
    

            Paillard said the fake Le Drian had done his homework, he even knew how many children he had.
    

            Wine maker Guy-Petrus Lignac was equally astonished at how much the fraudsters knew about him. He said they drew on his background to appeal to his sense of patriotism.  
    

      
      

      

    

            â€œThey knew so many things about me! That I had been a police officer in the past. Thatâ€™s not common knowledge, itâ€™s not on the internet. I was surprised,â€ Lignac told CNN. 
    

            Many of the victims were skeptical and went to the defense ministry to report the calls. The ministry alerted investigators in the summer of 2015 and an investigation was opened in April 2016, according to court documents.
    

            Lawyers for Le Drian said French embassies all over the world were warned of the scam in 2016. However, the ministry didnâ€™t see the need for a press conference. 
    

            Turkish businessman Inan Kirac, was duped in November 2016 and over the course of one month handed over $47 million in nine transfers to bank accounts in China â€“ the largest sum to be wired to the fraudsters by one individual.
    

            Kirac eventually realized he was being scammed and began taping the conversations.
    

            In an audio recording obtained by CNN Kirac is heard speaking with a man impersonating an aide to Le Drian.
    

            â€œMr. Kirac, first of all, I wanted to express my condolences concerning the attack in Istanbul and I learned that two of your very close friends were injured in this attack,â€ the voice on the crackly line is heard saying.
    

            â€œI hope that 2016 will be a good year to defeat crime and the terrorists who deserve to go to hell,â€ the man said.
    

            Kirac believed his money was being used to free two French journalists who were allegedly being held hostage in Syria.
    

            Delphine Meillet, the lawyer representing the actual Le Drian, who is now Franceâ€™s foreign minister, told CNN the fraudsters used the war in Syria to their advantage. 
    

            â€œThere were real hostages at the time, in 2015, and the technique to convince them was to play on fears of terrorism,â€ Meillet said.
    

            â€œWhen the state asks you to do it a favor, to help fight terrorism, how can you say no? How can you say no to a minister?â€ she added.
    

      
      

      

    

            The voice of the fake Le Drian is allegedly that of Gilbert Chikli, according to prosecutors, a Franco-Israeli accused of being the mastermind behind the sting. He is charged with organized fraud and usurping a personâ€™s identity. Chikli denies the charges.
    

            Meillet describes the 54-year-old as being a modern-day Victor Lustig, the notorious con man who sold the Eiffel Tower to a scrap-metal dealer in 1925, not once but twice.
    

            Chikli has a checkered past. In 2015, he was sentenced in absentia to seven years in prison for a brazen scam where he posed as prominent French CEOs in order to extort millions of euros from companies. The hoax was later the subject of a movie â€œThank You for Callingâ€ that paid Chikli as a consultant, according to court documents. 
    

            In 2017 the Parisian was arrested in Ukraine and according to court documents evidence was found on Chikliâ€™s cell phone showing that Google searches for â€œsilicone mask Kievâ€ and â€œPrince of Monacoâ€ had been made.â€
    

            Another defendant in the trial, Anthony Lasarevitsch, was arrested in Kiev alongside Chikli. Investigators found pictures of a silicone mask of Prince Albert II of Monaco on his cell phone.
    

            Lasarevitsch faces the same charges as Chikli, and denies any wrongdoing. His lawyer said in court that Lasarevitsch had been â€œdragged into the case by the mediaâ€ after his arrest alongside Chikli â€œwas broadcast to the masses.â€
    

            A clip of Chikli, while incarcerated in Kiev, surfaced on social media in 2017 showing him having a fridge delivered to the prison. In the video Chikli says â€œthis is what Iâ€™ve bought, a fridge, so I can eat some entrecote. We are the bosses!â€
    

            Chikli was eventually extradited to France. He is currently in prison serving time for the CEO hoax. Heâ€™s admitted taking part in the CEO scam but says heâ€™s not the mastermind.
    

            On Monday experts testified that the voice of the fake Le Drian bore a striking resemblance to that of Chikli.
    

            Chikli defended himself vehemently in court Monday.
    

            â€œWhat can I tell you? Theyâ€™ve got it wrong!â€ he shouted.  
    

            â€œThere are 20 billion cases like this per year, Iâ€™ve got nothing to do with this! I have no answers to your questions,â€ Chikli growled.
    

            His lawyer, Stephane Sebag, told CNN that the whole of the prosecution was based on weak analysis of the voice samples from Chikliâ€™s interviews and that the recordings of the scam â€œare very poor.â€
    

            â€œThis is not enough to convince anyone of his guilt,â€ Sebag said.
    

            If convicted Chikli faces up to 14 years in prison and a 2 million euro fine. A verdict is expected on March 11.
    

            The real Le Drian reacted to the scam last year. â€œYou canâ€™t impersonate me, if you do then you go to prison,â€ he said.
    

            â€œThey were pretty convincing and sadly there were victims. They did a good job of imitating my voice,â€ Le Drian added.  
    

  Fanny Bobille contributed to this report.

heading: Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal among critics of Novak Djokovicâ€™s new playersâ€™ association
article_content:
has been left divided following the launch of a breakaway playersâ€™ association, with 
and Rafael Nadal among those to criticize its formation. 
    

            The Professional Tennis Players Association (PTPA) was unveiled on Sunday as a body separate to the ATP Tour and tennisâ€™ first player-only council since 1972. 
    

            It is being spearheaded by world No. 1 Novak Djokovic and 94th-ranked Vasek Pospisil, who said it is â€œvery difficult, if not impossible, to have any significant impact on any major decisionsâ€ within the current structure alongside the ATP. 
    

            Djokovic, who continued his unbeaten streak in 2020 as he won the Western & Southern Open in New York, also said the current setup is â€œquite complex.â€
    

            He told reporters after his victory over 
: â€œThis is not a new idea. This hasnâ€™t been something that came out of the blue. This has been a project for many players and many different generations over the last 20-plus years.
    

            â€œI certainly think itâ€™s the right step forward for the players, because I think it unifies the players. It allows them to have a platform, to have an association through which they will be able to express themselves better where they will be able to talk about the ideas, the interests, and the things that are related to the players.â€
    

            He added that he believes the PTPA can coexist alongside the ATP Tour, but in a statement the governing body of menâ€™s tennis underlined the need for unity within the sport.
    

            

    

            â€œThe governance structure of the ATP Tour provides players with equal seats at the table on every major decision affecting the circuit. We recognize the challenges that our members face in todayâ€™s circumstances,â€ the statement read.
    

            â€œHowever we strongly believe that now is a time for unity, rather than internal division. We remain unwavering in our commitment to deliver for our players across all areas of our business, ensuring they receive maximum benefit from their years on Tour, and that their voices are heard.
    

            â€œIn parallel, we remain committed to working closely with the other governing bodies of tennis as we look to fulfill the true potential of our sport. Only as a unified sport can we truly focus on the fan experience, engage new audiences, and ensure that tennis continues to thrive.â€
    

            Federer and Nadal, the most decorated players in the menâ€™s game, spoke out against the PTPA.
    

      
      

      

    

            â€œThe world is living a difficult and complicated situation. I personally believe these are times to be calm and work all of us together in the same direction. It is time for unity, not for separation,â€ Nadal said on social media.
    

            â€œThese are moments where big things can be achieved as long as the world of tennis is united. We all, players, tournaments and governing bodies, have to work together. We have a bigger problem and separation and disunion is definitely not the solution.â€
    

            

    

            Federer, who earlier this year called for tennis to merge its menâ€™s and womenâ€™s governing bodies, agreed that it is time â€œto stand united as players, and as a sport,â€ while three-time grand slam champion Andy Murray questioned the absence of female players in the new association.
    

            Pospisil said there is â€œactive dialogue with the womenâ€™s sideâ€ to incorporate female players in the PTPA. 
    

            The launch of the association comes on the eve of the 
, which gets underway in Flushing Meadows on Monday.
    

            A number of top players will not play in the tournament amid the coronavirus pandemic, including Federer and Nadal on the menâ€™s side and top-ranked Ashleigh Barty and Simona Halep on the womenâ€™s. 
    

            Djokovic and Murray, who continues his return from a career-threatening hip injury, will compete in the menâ€™s draw, while Naomi Osaka and Serena Williams are among the high-profile participants in the womenâ€™s singles. 
    

            As in the NBA and the Champions League, players will live in bubbles around New York, either in tournament-sanctioned hotels or private accommodation.

heading: Tennis star Miyu Kato in tears as she struggles to answer questions about controversial disqualification
article_content:
A day after being controversially 
 from the 
 for inadvertently hitting a ball girl with a ball, an emotional 
struggled to answer questions about the incident. 
    

            Kato and her partner Aldila Sutjiadi were defaulted from the doubles event on Sunday after the Japanese player struck a ball girl having innocuously hit the ball to the back of the court following a point.
    

      
      

      

    

            Kato, who was seen crying on court after her disqualification, was back in action on Monday and reached the mixed doubles semifinals after winning in straight sets alongside German partner Tim Puetz. 
    

            Itâ€™s widely reported that Kato was in tears on court after winning the quarterfinal and was visibly emotional in the press conference afterward, leaving the room momentarily to compose herself before a question was answered. 
    

            â€œI think, first and foremost, weâ€™re all, including Miyu, happy that the ball girl is okay because obviously she got hit,â€ Puetz told reporters after coming back into the room with Kato. 
    

            â€œMiyu feels terrible about what happened. This was just very unfortunate for everyone, especially for her and the girl.â€ 
    

            A tearful Kato gave a very short answer in Japanese, saying it was difficult for her to speak English at this time. 
    

            While Puetz understood why officials made the decision, he said there was clearly no intent to hurt the ball girl. 
    

            â€œI understand she hit the ball girl. It was not intentional. I donâ€™t think it was in anger,â€ he added.
    

            â€œI think everybody saw the pictures. It wasnâ€™t anything malicious that she did. Nevertheless, it hit the ball girl.
    

            â€œThen two supervisors have to come on court, possibly didnâ€™t even see it. All they see is a crying ball girl who got hit with a ball. 
    

            â€œIn that moment, to make that decision, is very difficult.â€
    

            On Monday, Kato tweeted an apology to the ball girl, her doubles partner and her supporters, saying the incident was

    

            â€œI want to thank everyone for your continued support. I have received a worldwide outpouring of positive energy, and it has raised my spirits tremendously,â€ she 
, in a post which garnered support from other players. 
    

            â€œNow Iâ€™m onto the mixed doubles semifinals, where I will use every bit of that positive energy to succeed!â€ 
    

            According to the grand slam rule book, players â€œshall not violently, dangerously or with anger hit, kick or throw a tennis ball within the precincts of the tournament site except in the reasonable pursuit of a point during a match (including warm-up)â€
    

            The rule book states: â€œIn all cases of default, the decision of the referee in consultation with the grand slam chief of supervisors shall be final and unappealable.â€
    

            A player who is defaulted loses all ranking points earned at the tournament, the rule book states, and all prize money earned at the tournament.

heading: Schalke chairman Clemens TÃ¶nnies faces calls to quit after making racist comments
article_content:
The chairman of a leading German football club is under growing pressure to resign after making racist comments about African people during a speech last week.
    

            Schalke chairman Clemens TÃ¶nnies criticized tax increases to fight climate change while speaking at a
festival in the western city of Paderborn, suggesting instead that money be used to fund power plants in Africa.
    

            â€œThen the Africans would stop cutting down trees and stop producing children when itâ€™s dark,â€ TÃ¶nnies was quoted as saying by regional German 

    

            He has since apologized for his remarks and said he supports Schalkeâ€™s values against â€œracism, discrimination and exclusion.â€
    

            The club told CNN that their ethics body will be discussing his remarks soon, in an upcoming meeting.  
    

            â€œI would like to explicitly apologize to you, the fans, members and friends of FC Schalke 04,â€ TÃ¶nnies said in 
on the clubâ€™s website. â€œIt was wrong, thoughtless â€¦ and in no way met our mission statement. I am very sorry.â€ 
    

      
      

      

    

            But politicians and some fans of the Bundesliga club have urged him to quit, and the German Football Association (DFB) is under pressure to discipline the businessman.
    

            Germanyâ€™s Justice Minister Christine Lambrecht has led calls for TÃ¶nniesâ€™ comments to be punished. â€œRacism must be loudly and clearly contradicted,â€ she told newspapers of the Funke media group. 
    

            â€œNowhere is integration as successful and quick to work as in sport â€“ that must not be put at risk,â€ Lambrecht added.
    

            SDP lawmaker Markus TÃ¶ns 
: â€œThe racist statement by Clemens TÃ¶nnies at the â€œDay of Craftingâ€ in Paderborn is incompatible with the mission statement of Schalke 04.â€
    

            And Dagmar Freitag, who chairs the sports committee in Germanyâ€™s parliament, argued that TÃ¶nniesâ€™ apology cannot make up for the damage his remarks caused.
    

            â€œThat something like this (is) articulated by someone who holds a prominent position in the sport makes things even worse,â€ she told German newspaper Welt, adding that his explanation â€œcertainly can not make up for the socio-political damage.â€ 
    

            CNN has asked the DFB for comment.
    

            Schalke start their Bundesliga season on August 17. Last season, they finished 14th in Germanyâ€™s top division.

heading: Abidal pounces late as Barcelona edge â€˜El Clasicoâ€™ over Real Madrid
article_content:
Barcelona beat Real Madrid 2-1 in their Spanish Cup quarterfinal first leg tie
French defender strikes 13 minutes from time as holders suffer defeat at home stadium
Cristiano Ronaldo had given Real the lead before Carles Puyol equalized
Milan beat Novara to progress into the quarterfinals of the Italian Cup

            A late goal from Eric Abidal gave Barcelona a 2-1 comeback victory in the first leg of their Spanish Cup quarterfinal clash with arch rivals Real Madrid.
    

            The French defender scored the decisive goal in the match known as â€˜El Clasicoâ€™ at Realâ€™s Bernabeu stadium after Barcelona captain Carles Puyol had canceled out Cristiano Ronaldoâ€™s opener.
    

            It means Barcelona are favorites to progress into the final four of the competition and eliminate the holders when the two contest the second leg next Wednesday.
    

            After a cagey opening, in which Barcelona dominated possession, Real took the lead with their first meaningful attack on 11 minutes.
    

            Karim Benzemaâ€™s pass found Ronaldo scampering through the middle, and the Portuguese forward stepped past Gerard Pique before firing beyond Barca keeper Pinto.
    

            Ronaldo, who has been criticized by some fans for not celebrating some of his recent goals and for missing several chances in the last match with Barca, certainly looked like he enjoyed his opener.
    

            Five minutes later Barcelona striker Alexis Sanchez, from Chile, got on the end of Cesc Fabregasâ€™ pass but though his looping header beat Real goalkeeper Iker Casillas, it bounced back off the post.
    

            Lionel Messi had his first sight of goal on 26 minutes as his low shot forced Casillas into a smart save at his near post. Andres Iniesta then made some room inside the penalty area but he fired wide after Sanchezâ€™s lay off.
    

            But just three minutes into the second half Barcelona pulled level as their captain Carles Puyol stooped to head a corner into the net.
    

            Moments later Real defender Sergio Ramos deflected a volley from Iniesta onto the woodwork after a chipped pass from Fabregas.
    

            Real then hit the woodwork themselves as Benzemaâ€™s header cannoned back off the upright with Pinto beaten.
    

            Tempers frayed when Realâ€™s Pepe appeared to stamp on Messiâ€™s hand as the Argentine was on the floor after a foul before Barca edged in front with just over ten minutes to go.
    

            Abidal, who signed a new contract at the club this week, controlled Messiâ€™s pass on his chest before shooting low into the net.
    

            In Italy, 
progressed to the quarterfinals of the Italian Cup but they needed extra time to beat Novara 2-1.
    

            Stephan El Shaarawy gave the Rossoneri the lead on 24 minutes with a curling shot but Ivan Radovanovic equalized for Serie Aâ€™s bottom club with a long range free kick two minutes from time.
    

            It was left to Milanâ€™s Brazilian striker Pato to seal victory, ten minutes into the extra half an hour.

heading: Lewis Hamilton hints at Formula One exit if calendar expands further
article_content:
The Formula One season is the longest it has ever been.
    

            In 2018, for the second time in three years, drivers and teams have competed over the course of a 21-race season, spending more time away from families and homes.
    

            Now, with the announcement of a Vietnamese Grand Prix being added to the calendar from 2020, Lewis Hamilton has expressed his concern that the season is becoming unbearably long.
    

            

    

            

    

            â€œI am not going to be here if it gets to 25 races, thatâ€™s for sure,â€ Hamilton told reporters. 
    

            â€œIt already feels like we are on race 25 this year, so I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a good thing. I think 18 was probably the best back in the day.â€
    

            Despite next year also featuring 21 races, the schedule in 2019 means the F1 calendar will run into December for the first time in over 50 years.
    

            Liberty Media, the company that has owned Formula One since January 2017, has often expressed its hopes of expanding the season further.
    

            â€œIâ€™m someone who really loves racing but the season is long,â€ Hamilton said. â€œItâ€™s a lot of commitment for all of us and a lot of time away from families, and the seasons are getting longer and the off time is getting shorter.
    

            â€œAll I can do is speak is for myself. The turnaround is so short, you start preparing for your next season often as soon as the season is done. 
    

            â€œGetting your mind turned. Thatâ€™s very difficult. Then you have to find a way of switching off and recovering at the same time.â€
    

            Hamilton wrapped up his fifth world title in Mexico a fortnight ago but the constructorsâ€™ championship is still to be decided.
    

            Ferrari must better Mercedesâ€™ score in Brazil this weekend by 13 points or more if they want the title race to go to the season finale in Abu Dhabi.

heading: Russian convoy rolls into Ukraine: â€˜Humanitarianâ€™ aid or â€˜direct invasionâ€™?
article_content:
White House: Obama, Merkel agree Russian convoy is "a provocation"
UK ambassador: Convoy "has nothing to do with humanitarianism"
Lithuania official: Consul kidnapped, killed by "terrorists"
Putin blames Ukraine, says it'd be "unacceptable" to delay sending convoy

            Is it an act of compassion or one of belligerence? 
    

            Both judgments were offered Friday on the dozens of Russian trucks that have rolled into eastern Ukraine, a move Russian leaders cast as necessary to address a humanitarian crisis and a Ukrainian official characterized as an â€œinvasionâ€ of his nation by its mighty neighbor to the east.
    

            While getting agreement on the right answer is impossible at this moment, thereâ€™s little doubt the actions have raised tensions to new levels â€“ and thatâ€™s saying something, given the volatility over the past many months.
    

            The latest row revolves around aid going from Russia to Ukraine. Kiev had stalled trucks on the Russian side of the border for days, before acknowledging Sunday that the convoy, in fact, had humanitarian aid.
    

            That admission didnâ€™t end the discord and debate. As of 11:30 p.m. (4:30 p.m. ET) Friday, 227 Russian vehicles had crossed into Ukraine, according to the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, which has an observer mission at the checkpoint the convoy went through.
    

            All the vehicles were supposed to be monitored by members of the International Committee of the Red Cross. However, the Red Cross said it wasnâ€™t accompanying them due to the â€œvolatile security situationâ€ â€“ a reference to continued fighting between pro-Russian rebels and Ukrainian forces.
    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

            Ukraine has repeatedly accused Russia of directly and indirectly bolstering the rebel movement. The Kiev-based government and its allies â€“ including the NATO alliance and its core member, the United States â€“ see this convoy as perhaps Moscowâ€™s most glaring, egregious move yet.
    

            â€œWe call this a direct invasion for the first time under cynical cover of the Red Cross,â€ said Valentyn Nalyvaychenko, the head of Ukraineâ€™s security service.
    

            Right now, Ukraine isnâ€™t planning to go after the convoy. Still, Nalyvaychenko thinks its main purpose is to supply rebels and its drivers are not even civilians.
    

            To Russian President Vladimir Putin, it is Ukraineâ€™s government â€“ not his â€“ thatâ€™s being irresponsible and fueling instability in eastern Ukraine. 
    

            Putin expressed â€œserious concernâ€ to German Chancellor Angela Merkel about endangered civilians and other impacts from Ukraineâ€™s â€œcontinued (military) escalation,â€ according to the Kremlin.
    

            He further criticized what he characterized as â€œKievâ€™s blatant attempts to hinder the delivery of Russian humanitarian aidâ€ into southeast Ukraine, implying he had no choice but to act.
    

            â€œFurther delay would have been unacceptable,â€ a Kremlin statement said.
    

            

    

            The international community hardly embraced Putinâ€™s version of events.
    

            The British ambassador to the United Nations said that Russia had no support at a U.N. Security Council meeting Friday on the topic. The diplomat, Mark Lyall Grant, made no doubt about his own countryâ€™s views on the convoyâ€™s entrance into Ukraine.
    

            â€œIt is an undeniable and blatant violation of Ukrainian sovereignty and clear breach of international law and the U.N. charter,â€ Lyall Grant told reporters. â€œIt has nothing to do with humanitarianism.â€
    

            NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen warned that the the â€œso-called humanitarian convoy â€¦ can only deepen the crisis in the region, which Russia itself has created and has continued to fuel.â€
    

            â€œThe disregard of international humanitarian principles raises further questions about whether the true purpose of the aid convoy is to support civilians or to resupply armed separatists,â€ Rasmussen said in a statement.       
    

            Merkel talked not only with Putin â€“ during which she voiced her â€œgrave concernâ€ â€“ but also with U.S. President Barack Obama.
    

            The two leaders agreed that Ukraine â€œhas continued to deteriorate since the tragic downingâ€ of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, purportedly by pro-Russian rebels, the White House said. The pair concurred, too, that the convoy â€œis a further provocation and a violation of Ukraineâ€™s sovereigntyâ€ and called for the stop â€œof Russian personnel, military equipment and armored vehicles into eastern Ukraine.â€
    

            Other U.S. officials laid into Russia publicly.
    

            Pentagon spokesman Rear Adm. John Kirby said that Moscow has been told in â€œvery, very clear (terms) that they should not be doing this under the guise of a humanitarian convoy, to use that as an excuse to cross the border in a non-authorized way.â€
    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

            â€œRussia must remove its vehicles and its personnel from the territory of Ukraine immediately,â€ Kirby told reporters. â€œFailure to do so will result in additional costs and isolation.â€
    

        Russia must remove its vehicles and its personnel from the territory of Ukraine immediately.
    

            Pentagon spokesman John Kirby
        

            This view was seconded by Deputy National Security Adviser Ben Rhodes, who deemed the convoy â€“ which he said his nation and its allies are tracking closely â€“ â€œas part of a pattern of flagrant violation of Ukrainian sovereignty.â€ The more Moscow does such things that stir instability in Ukraine, the more it will pay, according to Rhodes.
    

            â€œIf (Russia does) not remove the convoys, we will be making determinations with our international partners about how to ratchet up the costs and consequences on them,â€ Rhodes said.
    

            

    

            Itâ€™s not just the Russian vehicles that crossed into Ukraine that are causing consternation. So, too, are the Russian troops massed at the border.
    

            There were up to 18,000 such â€œcombat-readyâ€ troops on Friday, a significant increase from previous public estimates by the Pentagon, according to a U.S. defense official with direct access to the latest information. 
    

            The official described the units as being in a â€œfully combat-capable offensive posture.â€
    

            A second U.S. official said that many of the units were positioned at â€œcrossroads and townsâ€ two to 10 miles from the border. 
    

            â€œThey are definitely more overt, aggressive and out in the open,â€ the official said. â€œThey arenâ€™t even hiding it.â€
    

            The second official said the United States has believed for weeks that some Russian troops have crossed the border as part of the convoys of military gear and weapons moving from Russia into Ukraine.
    

            Of particular concern is the apparent transport of long-range and advanced systems including at least two SA-22 surface-to-air missile system and a number of pieces of longer-range artillery.
    

            The fear is that any advance of any kind could make the ongoing fighting â€“ sparked last year by a political crisis over whether Ukraine would seek closer ties with Europe or Russia â€“ even worse. U.N. officials estimate that more than 2,000 people have died and nearly 5,000 have been wounded in eastern Ukraine since mid-April.
    

            The dead include Mykola Zelenec, Lithuaniaâ€™s honor consul in the eastern Ukrainian city of Luhansk, who Lithuanian Foreign Minister Linas Linkevicius said had been â€œkidnapped and brutally killed by terrorists.â€
    

            Ukraine has time and again accused Russia of effectively fomenting rebellion by supporting rebels â€“ including militarily â€“ in eastern Ukraine, some of whom continue to hold territory there despite a push by Ukraineâ€™s military.
    

            Russia has denied any direct support for the rebels while voicing sympathy for their fight for self-determination, saying that Kiev is in the wrong for its actions that endanger civilians â€“ including many ethnic Russians.
    

            Even if the Russian military doesnâ€™t explicitly march into Ukraine, there are concerns that it will find other ways to bolster the rebels.
    

            Russiaâ€™s ambassador to the United Nations, Vitaly Churkin, insisted Friday that the current humanitarian convoy wonâ€™t be one of them.
    

            He told reporters that Russia received â€œofficial acceptance by Kiev authoritiesâ€ for the convoy, and that Moscow is staying in touch with Ukrainian officials to make sure there are no problems in the process of distribution of the aid.
    

            

    

            

    

            

    

  CNNâ€™s Lindsay Isaac â€“ along with journalist Victoria Butenko â€“ reported from Kiev, and CNNâ€™s Greg Botelho reported and wrote from Atlanta. CNNâ€™s Laura Smith-Spark, Jason Hanna and Olga Pavlova contributed to this report.

heading: Liverpool stars Mohamed Salah and Sadio Mane to face off in AFCON final
article_content:
Liverpool teammates 
and Sadio Mane will come face to face in the Africa Cup of Nations (AFCON) final after Egypt booked its place in Sundayâ€™s game. 
    

            
 was awaiting the winner of Thursdayâ€™s semifinal between Cameroon and Egypt and, despite the host having the better chances, it was the Pharaohs who progressed on penalties. 
    

            Egyptian goalkeeper Mohamed Abou Gabal produced two brilliant saves in the shootout before Cameroonâ€™s Clinton Njie fired his penalty wide of the post to send Egypt through after a goalless draw. 
    

            Egypt will now be bidding for a record-extending eighth AFCON title while Senegal looks to win its first. 
    

            Sundayâ€™s final will also be the first of three matches between the two sides in the coming months with the teams pitted against each other in a two-legged playoff for a place in this yearâ€™s World Cup in Qatar. 
    

            Both Salah and Mane have spearheaded Liverpoolâ€™s success in recent seasons and they now carry the hopes of their nations on their backs. 
    

            Neither have been in lightning form during this yearâ€™s tournament but both have still scored goals, Mane netting three times and Salah twice. 
    

            

    

            Senegal last reached an AFCON final in 2019, eventually losing 1-0 to Algeria, and the current crop of players will certainly be feeling the weight of expectation to finally end the countryâ€™s wait for a title.
