  CNNâ€™s George Ramsay and Matt Foster contributed to reporting.

heading: Hines Ward: Making a playoff push is the NFL dream
article_content:
Iâ€™ve always said this year has kind of been, really, the year of the quarterbacks. Drew Brees becoming the all-time leading passer, Tom Bradyâ€™s still doing his thing at the age of 41. But I kind of see the young guns, the young quarterbacks that are rising.
    

            My Steelers won Super Bowl XLIII in 2009, but the following season we ended up missing the playoffs despite winning the last three games, finishing 9-7 and not losing a single game by more than six points. Itâ€™s a letdown because you know you still have the talent in place and the ingredients to find success. But on the flip side, you realize what a blessing it is to get a chance in the first place. 
    

            Iâ€™ve played with guys who never even came close to making the playoffs. 
    

            Playing in the playoffs and really making that push towards a Super Bowl is really what we live for as football players. Itâ€™s what we get paid for and, honestly, I know a lot of people that would do it for free. Thatâ€™s what you dreamed about when you were a little kid, because thereâ€™s nothing like playing in the Super Bowl. 
    

            It was hard for us, because when youâ€™re in those last few weeks, you want to control your own destiny. You donâ€™t want to have to worry about needing help to get into the playoffs, hoping other teams lose and worrying about whether other teams are going to end up resting players because they have their spot already locked up. Itâ€™s hard to not take a peek up at that scoreboard while youâ€™re playing and see what else is going on. 
    

            You can kind of see the similarities with the Eagles this year. They still have a lot of their key pieces from their Super Bowl run and win, but theyâ€™ve been struggling to keep things consistent. Theyâ€™ve got a sense of urgency because they know the temperature is getting hotter, especially because they know they have to win out and still get a little bit of help along the way. 
    

            Theyâ€™re still a good team, just like we were still a good team in 2009-10 (we ended up making the Super Bowl that next year). For the Eagles to have been able to beat the Rams last week, thatâ€™s impressive, especially on the road. When it comes to Nick Foles, the guyâ€™s just been able to get it done in Philly. The team rallies around him, so weâ€™ll see if heâ€™s able to pull off some of the same magic as last year. 
    

            Thatâ€™s the fun and uniqueness of making a playoff push. Teams that control their own destiny, kudos to them for getting it done. And if youâ€™re one of those teams where your season is going to come down to the last weekend, it makes for an exciting ride. 
    

            
 It seems like theyâ€™re on the verge of getting over the hump and theyâ€™ve got plenty of young talent around them. Theyâ€™ve already won more games this season than they have in the last three years. 
    

            
There was so much pressure on him, from being a Heisman winner to being the top pick, to Cleveland having looked for a quarterback for so long. I love what he brings to the table. I love that heâ€™s â€“ I wouldnâ€™t say cocky, but confident. You want a quarterback who has that moxie, because when youâ€™re in the huddle, everybody else builds off that.

heading: Jackie Stewart: Fernando Alonso will have â€˜no trouble at allâ€™ on comeback
article_content:
Fernando Alonso will have â€œno trouble at allâ€ as he targets a return to Formula One at the Malaysia Grand Prix after his freakish crash in winter testing.
    

            The McLaren driver 
on the advice of his doctors but will drive in Sundayâ€™s race if he passes a medical assessment by the sportâ€™s governing body, the FIA, at the Sepang circuit on Thursday.
    

            Jackie Stewart, a three-time world champion and leading motorsport safety campaigner, told CNN: â€œAlonso will deal with that, no trouble at all. 
    

            â€œHeâ€™s probably got the best head of any racing driver right now. 
    

            â€œRacing drivers always have accidents of some kind and come back very resilient and better trained. Their physical condition is very good and they are better prepared for racing today than in the history of the sport.â€
    

            Alonso is renown for his mental strength and the Spanish double world champion has also posted regular updates on social media describing his physical training, including photos of him pumping iron, in the build up to Malaysia.
    

            The CNN-sponsored McLaren team said since his testing accident in Barcelona he has â€œfollowed a rigorous, specialized training programâ€¦ to ensure his safe and timely return to racing.â€
    

            Alonso was 
after losing control of his McLaren at the penultimate winter test at Barcelonaâ€™s Circuit de Catalunya on February 22.
    

            The 33-year-old watched the Melbourne race from his home in Dubai after doctors indicated returning to racing three weeks after a high impact crash was too risky.
    

            McLaren said senior engineers discussed the accident with Alonso when he visited the teamâ€™s headquarters outside London last week. 
    

            The team said in a statement: â€œWhile there was nothing evident in the extensive car telemetry data, nor anything abnormal in the subsequent reconstructions and laboratory tests, Fernando recalls a sense of â€˜heavyâ€™ steering prior to the accident.â€
    
Sir Jackie Stewart has been in the spotlight for 
 today 

            Stewart believes Alonso and his team made the right decision not to race in Australia, even though it meant delaying the star driverâ€™s return to the McLaren cockpit after five years with Ferrari.
    

            â€œI donâ€™t have any doubt at all that his doctors did exactly the right thing and that he had made the right decision personally to follow the instructions of their medical team,â€ Sir Jackie told CNN. â€œI look forward to see him back in the cockpit.â€
    

            Williams driver Valtteri Bottas is also facing an FIA medical Thursday after he was unable to take part in the Melbourne race following a back injury sustained during qualifying.
    

            â€œAfter such a frustrating Sunday in Australia, I have taken the necessary measures to make sure I arrive in Malaysia fit to race and ready to bring the results home,â€ said the in-form Finnish driver.
    

      
      

      

    

            Stewart says it is important that F1 continues to protect its drivers, even if it means insisting they sit out races.
    

            The most serious accident in recent times has left Marussia racer 
 and fighting serious head injuries following a crash in wet conditions at the Japanese Grand Prix last October.
    

            â€œWe shouldnâ€™t take it for granted that drivers are bulletproof,â€ warned Sir Jackie, who raced in an era of frequent fatalities in the 1960s and 1970s.
    

            â€œMotor racing is still dangerous. People are surviving accidents but you are this far from death sometimes. 
    

            â€œYouâ€™ve got to recognize that and you cannot be irresponsible. Liberties are being taken today that I prefer are not taken. You can always improve safety.â€

heading: Simon Le Bon: How sailing changed Duran Duran singerâ€™s life
article_content:
Duran Duran lead singer Simon Le Bon was at the height of his fame in 1985 when his life was turned upside down.
    

            Le Bon, front man of iconic 1980s British pop band, was competing in the Fastnet yacht race â€“ a 608-mile round trip between the Isle of Wight and Plymouth off Britainâ€™s southwest coast.
    

            He was asleep aboard his 78-foot maxi-yacht Drum when the keel broke off the hull due to a design failure.
    

            The boat capsized, trapping Le Bon and five other crew members inside. Although the alarm was raised straight away by another yacht, Carat, the men were stuck inside the upturned yacht for 40 minutes until they were rescued.
    

            The incident had a profound impact on Le Bon, one of the biggest popstars of the 1980s who just one month before had performed to a worldwide television audience of 1.5 billion as part of Live Aid.
    

            â€œIt really did frighten me,â€ Le Bon told CNN Sport in an interview at last monthâ€™s Southampton Boat Show.
    

            â€œItâ€™s something you donâ€™t realize until after the event,â€ said Le Bon, an avid sailor since his youth, with one of the pop groupâ€™s early hits â€“ â€œRioâ€ â€“ featuring the band members on a yacht in Antigua in the accompanying video.
    

            â€œAbout two or three days after it happened, I broke out into this rash, all over my chest, and all over my arms. I am sure it was a stress-related thing. I just couldnâ€™t sleep, because I was asleep when the keel went,â€ he said, reflecting on the 1985 capsize.
    

            In 2016, Le Bon watched footage of his dramatic rescue, near Falmouth in Cornwall, by the Royal National Lifeboat Institute and a helicopter from the 771 Royal Naval Air Squadron, for the first time as part of a BBC documentary.  
    

            â€œI had to go down to come up,â€ he told the BBC. â€œI dived in and started going up â€“ as I came up the waistband of my long johns got caught and pulled down.â€
    

            â€œAs I came up to the surface I stopped about two feet away. I wanted to breathe but if I did I knew that would be the end of me. 
    

            â€œI managed to get them off my feet and came up with a big smile on my face.
    

            â€œI got winched off into the helicopter and one of the guys called â€˜Hey Simon, whereâ€™s your pants?â€™ because I was just stood there in my knickers.â€
    

            Television footage showed the singer back on shore with bare legs. 
    

            â€œThereâ€™s me â€¦ a rock star in his underpants,â€ Le Bon told the BBC.
    

            

    

            

    

            Although Le Bon had entered Drum in the Fastnet as a test event for the 1985-1986 Whitbread Round the World race, he had second thoughts about taking part in the circumnavigation.
    

            A phone call from his experienced American skipper, Skip Novak, three weeks after the capsize changed his mind.
    

            â€œHe said â€˜Hey Simon â€¦ weâ€™re going to fix her up. And the Whitbread people have agreed to delay the start of the race a whole month so that we can enter,â€™â€ Le Bon said in Southampton.
    

            â€œAnd I said â€˜Skip, I donâ€™t think I can do it. It just terrified me, and I am still suffering.â€™ And he went: â€˜Simon, England expects!â€™ And I thought, â€˜Oh, OK, OK.â€™â€ 
    

            

    

            The first few days back on board werenâ€™t easy.
    

            â€œIt was tough, and I remember the first night on the boat that I spent after that, I was rigid,â€ Le Bon said. â€œI was like a bow, with my head on the pillow, and my feet on the bed and air between the rest of me and mattress, I was terrified that first night.
    

            â€œBut the second night wasnâ€™t as bad, and the third night was almost OK, and the fourth night, I went to sleep and had a good time, and I woke up in the morning and I thought â€˜Iâ€™m at sea, and itâ€™s wonderful.â€™â€
    

            Drum would eventually finish third in elapsed time in the Whitbread, which has since changed its name to the Volvo Ocean Race. 
    

            The story of Le Bonâ€™s dramatic rescue created headlines around the world, and more than 10,000 spectator boats welcomed Drum back to British shores. 
    

            When asked if the experience had been life-changing, Le Bon said: â€œYes, it was. But we all have life-changing experiences. It was a particularly well-publicized one. Thatâ€™s the big difference. People trip over a curb and it could be life-changing. These things happen. Itâ€™s just part of being human, we all go through these things.â€
    

            The capsize also had a big impact on Novak, an expert in polar sailing who would compete in four Whitbread Round the World races.
    

            â€œThere is something singular about having shared a life-threatening experience, the day we found ourselves upside-down in the English Channel,â€ Novak wrote in a column for Yachting World in 2016. 
    

            â€œThe refit against all the odds strengthened that bond and stood us in good stead for the protracted challenge of the Whitbread race itself, which was no mere outing. It was not the accomplishment that mattered most, but rather the total experience.â€  
    

            Le Bon, a father-of-three who turns 60 at the end of October, still performs with Duran Duran. Although he sold Drum in 1988 to Scottish businessman Arnold Clark, he also still sails regularly in regattas and owns a wooden motor boat thatâ€™s moored in Italy. 
    

            Le Bon, who recently became a grandfather with his wife, Yasmin, has been a long-serving ambassador of The Blue Marine Foundation (BLUE), which aims to combat the effects of over-fishing and the destruction of biodiversity on the worldâ€™s oceans by creating large marine reserves.
    
Pandemonium as Simon Le Bon (Millennials: thats lead singer of Duran Duran), opens 
 

            He is hugely concerned about the future of the worldâ€™s oceans.
    

            â€œAs a recreational boater and a swimmer, I want to go down into an undersea park when I put my snorkle and mask on,â€ he said.
    

            â€œI want to see fish, I want to see lots of different life, I donâ€™t want to see a dead, gray sea floor, which in the Mediterranean, is really what youâ€™ve got right now. And thatâ€™s going to take a lot of work.â€

heading: EU leaders offer nearly $2 billion in aid to Africa to stem migrant crisis
article_content:
EU sets up fund of nearly $2 billion aid to Africa to stem the migrant crisis
Sweden to implement temporary border controls 
At least 18 died Wednesday in two boat accidents off Turkey

            As Europe faces its worst refugee crisis since World War II, the European Union has launched an emergency fund for Africa to tackle the spiraling number of migrants flooding its shores.
    

            The nearly $2 billion fund was unveiled at the end of a two-day summit of EU and African leaders in Malta. The fund will support projects to combat poverty, slow down migration and speed up repatriation programs. This new money is in addition to the 20 billion euros annually donated to Africa by the EU and its 28 states.
    

            This is the sixth time that presidents and prime ministers of the European Union have tried to tackle the issue.
    

            â€œWe are under no illusions that we can improve the situation overnight, but we are committed to giving people alternatives to risking their lives,â€ said European Council President Donald Tusk.
    

            Tusk listed five major goals to stem the tide of migrants: â€œThe elements of action plan are designed to, one, address the root causes of migration; two, enhance cooperation on legal migration and mobility; three, reinforce protection of displaced persons; four, prevent and fight against migrant smuggling and trafficking in human beings; and five, advance on returning persons that are not entitled to stay in Europe.â€ 
    

            Maltese Prime Minister Joseph Muscat said that while some may argue that the fund was not enough, he stressed it was an important first step. 
    

            The Mediterranean island nation of Malta is the smallest member of the European Union. About 90 kilometers (56 miles) south of Sicily, it has become one of the destinations for those fleeing Syriaâ€™s bloody civil war. 
    

            â€œI for one am a very vocal critic of the fact that we maybe started acting a little bit too late when too many lives were lost at sea,â€ Muscat said, adding that he hoped the summit â€œsowed the seeds of something that can be much more long term.â€ 
    

            European Council President Tusk also confirmed plans for a summit with Turkey by the end of this year, seen as the key to resolving the crisis. 
    

            After an informal meeting of EU heads after the summit, Tusk said â€œthe clock is ticking. We are under pressure. We need to act fast. As a union. And in cooperation with our partners, including Turkey, that also will have to move fast. 
    

            â€œBut Turkey cannot be our only partner. We must not lose sight of Jordan and Lebanon, nor of the countries of the Western Balkans. They are also our allies.â€
    

            Even as Europe tries to forge a unified response to the crisis, tens of thousands continue to embark on perilous journeys, desperate to escape the repression, violence, poverty and insecurity in North Africa, West Africa and the Middle East.
    

            They come from more than 20 nations and with different motivations. 

    

            Many die in their attempt to find a safe haven.
    

            On Wednesday, hours before the EU meeting was scheduled to convene, at least 18 people died off the western coast of Turkey in two boat incidents. 
    

            Mountains of life jackets piled up on the beaches of the Greek island of Lesbos offer a startling testimony to the scale of the problem.
    

            The EU border agency Frontex, which tracks the movement of people, says 540,000 migrants arrived on Greek islands in the first 10 months of 2015. This figure is 13 times higher than in the same period of 2014. 
    

            Syrians account for the largest number of arrivals, according to the Frontex website. In recent weeks, the share of Afghan nationals has risen significantly.
    

            Frontex has called for more than 250 officers to help screen, fingerprint and register migrants.
    

            Meanwhile, Sweden has joined the list of countries that have tightened border controls.
    

            The Ministry of Home Affairs said it will implement temporary border controls for 10 days, and they could be extended to 20 days at some point, according to Fredrik Persson, a spokesman for the ministry.
    

            Swedenâ€™s Prime Minister Stefan LÃ¶fven defended the move, telling CNN: â€œThis is not closing the border, the decision we have taken is to reintroduce internal border controls â€¦ if a person comes to our country seeking asylum he or she will be given that opportunity.â€ 
    

  CNNâ€™s Ed Payne and Damien Ward contributed to this report

heading: The far-right is changing the face of the EUâ€™s third biggest city
article_content:
A far-right party is exerting its political influence in the Spanish capital of Madrid, starting with its Christmas lights. 
    

            Vox made a pact with the conservative Partido Popular (PP), which rules the cityâ€™s regional government, earlier this year. And the far-right party, a newcomer on Spainâ€™s political scene, has already made its presence felt.
    

            It has seized on cultural issues, and last month secured commitments to increase spending and religious imagery on Christmas decorations around Madrid. Vox has also opposed attempts to improve gender equality and pushed for a new family department to promote what it describes as traditional values.
    

            Each of these policies touches on key issues for Vox, which won four out of 57 seats in Mayâ€™s Madrid council elections. It then entered negotiations with the PP over policy concessions in exchange for support in crucial council votes. The PP formed the city government in August.
    

            Vox burst onto the political scene in 2018 after taking an unexpectedly high number of seats in the election in Andalusia, Spainâ€™s largest region. Not only did
the result accord the party influence through its crucial support for a PP-led alliance, it also marked something of a watershed â€“ as the first time a far-right party had entered a regional parliament since the death of dictator Francisco Franco in 1975.
    

            It then won 24 out of a total 350 seats in the national parliament in Aprilâ€™s general election, a slightly disappointing result for the party after its Andalusian success, according to some political experts, but one which nonetheless cemented its place as a new political force. 
    

            Vox has attracted voters with its hard line stance on illegal immigration, its opposition to Catalan independence and its calls for Gibraltar to be returned to Spain, as well as an emphasis on cultural traditions, which were raised recently in Madrid.
    

            A Vox spokesman told CNN that the previous regional government had removed all religious symbolism from Christmas decorations in the city, but his party wants to reemphasize the Christian tradition of the festival. â€œWe are not telling people how they should celebrate Christmas but from the institutions we should be accurate and respect the Spanish culture, the Catholic culture,â€ he said.
    

            This year there will be more lights, larger decorations and new designs that focus on traditional Christmas images. Nativity scenes will be installed at several of the cityâ€™s symbolic monumental gates.
    

            Festive decorations are just one symbolic issue that Vox has taken up. The party doesnâ€™t control any council departments and officially remains in opposition. But Voxâ€™s pact with PP means Isabel DÃ­az Ayuso, Madridâ€™s regional leader, has promised to develop a program with concessions to Vox. 
    

      
      

      

    

            â€œIâ€™ll honor it completely because thatâ€™s my word,â€ said Ayuso in reference to the pact, which includes provisions forcing schools to inform parents about the content of lessons before the start of term, and changes to the way in which unaccompanied migrant children are identified.
    

            A Vox spokesman told CNN that there have been mistakes in identifying foreign unaccompanied minors and that there have been cases of people pretending to be children in order to claim certain state benefits.
    

            â€œWe demand that a new way of identification is put in place so we can correctly identify the people who have the right to those benefits,â€ the spokesman said, emphasizing that Vox has zero tolerance for illegal migration. â€œWe would like those benefits to go to legal and regulated immigration.â€
    

            A PP spokeswoman told CNN the identification of minors is the responsibility of the central prosecutorâ€™s office for minors, not regional politicians. The spokeswoman emphasized that any policy changes would have to be made at a national level, rather than by the local Madrid government.
    

            Madridâ€™s PP mayor, JosÃ© Luis MartÃ­nez-Almeida, will need Voxâ€™s votes again to pass a budget and other essential business. 
    

            However Almeida and Vox spokesman Javier Ortega Smith have already suffered a very public disagreement, arguing in the street in full view of the press and the public on September 19. As Almeida and other public figures observed a minuteâ€™s silence in honor of a victim of gender-based violence, Ortega Smith disrupted proceedings holding a sign that read: â€œViolence has no gender.â€ 
    

            Speaking about the incident, the Vox spokesman expressed his condolences with the family of the victim. â€œIt was just a way of expressing our condolences from another point of view,â€ he said. â€œAll victims are the same, they shouldnâ€™t be treated differently because of their gender.â€ 
    

            Almeida said that he thought Vox had made a mistake in bringing the banner to the memorial. However the mayor also emphasized that he â€œdoes not believe in gender ideologyâ€ and that the struggle for equality between men and women should be â€œwithout ideology.â€ 
    

      
      

      

    

            Despite the public row, Almeida said that there was nothing â€œuncomfortableâ€ about the arrangement between Vox and the PP. â€œI donâ€™t see any issues with the relationship with Vox other than some disagreements that can be solved,â€ he said at a press conference.
    

            However Yolanda Besteiro, president of feminist organization FundaciÃ³n de Mujeres Progresistas, told CNN that she is worried and saddened by the PP-Vox pact and Almeidaâ€™s statements on gender equality. â€œItâ€™s dangerous,â€ she said, warning that the PP is legitimizing the far-right. â€œItâ€™s a setback in the implementation of gender equality policies.â€
    

            With a relationship that includes significant concessions to Voxâ€™ policy program, some had worried that the far-right was controlling the Madrid government. However Maria JosÃ© Canel, professor of political and public sector communication at the Universidad Complutense de Madrid, told CNN that the situation is more nuanced. â€œIt (Vox) holds an important position but not as important as it had hoped,â€ she said. â€œVox is not directly imposing conditions on the local government in Madrid.â€
    

            The party secured fewer concessions than it had originally asked for from the PP, according to Canel, and has adopted a less controversial approach in the run-up to new national elections on November 10. â€œI think theyâ€™re going to maintain this softer approach until they work out how many votes they can get,â€ she said.
    

            However, by staying out of government the party has made a strong strategic move, she added. â€œIt is able to keep its hands free to raise objections and make public declarations against (the government),â€ said Canel, explaining that it would not have been able to do so if it took control of a council department.
    

            As for Voxâ€™s place in the far-right ecosystem, Canel warns against drawing easy comparisons. â€œThe far-right movement in Spain does not fit the same characteristics as far-right movements in other countries,â€ she said. 
    

            Canel said that Vox is not as â€œskillfulâ€ as other far-right groups, and pointed out that the vast majority of Spanish voters are in favor of the European Union. Other European far-right movements use opposition to the EU as a rallying cry, something that Vox is unable to do. So the party exists in a specific Spanish context which sets it apart from other far-right groups.
    

            Canel also shut down the idea of deep cooperation between Vox and other far-right figures such as Italyâ€™s interior minister Matteo Salvini of the Northern League party, who has himself been advised by US President Donald Trumpâ€™s former chief strategist, Steve Bannon. â€œItâ€™s not that simple,â€ she said.

heading: MH17 tributes in Moscow: â€˜Forgive usâ€™
article_content:
Nearly two-thirds of those who died in the Malaysia Airlines crash in Ukraine were Dutch
In Moscow, people have been leaving flowers and toys outside the Dutch Embassy
Many of the messages include the phrase "forgive me," CNN's Diana Magnay says
One Muscovite told her that Russia's connections with rebels meant it was involved

            Outside the Dutch Embassy in Moscow, people have left flowers and cuddly toys at a makeshift memorial for the lives lost in a conflict-scarred corner of eastern Ukraine.
    

            Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 fell from the sky in Donetsk on Thursday, killing all aboard. Of the 298 people killed, 193 â€“ nearly two-thirds â€“ were Dutch citizens.   
    

            The United States accuses Moscow of supporting the pro-Russian rebels that it suspects shot down the aircraft. 
    

            Russia denies involvement, with Russian President Vladimir Putin saying Ukraineâ€™s military operation against the rebels is to blame for the tragedy. He has called for a â€œthorough and objectiveâ€ investigation.
    

            With rebels in control of the crash area, and reports of bodies and wreckage being tampered with, Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte told reporters he had a â€œvery intenseâ€ conversation with Putin on Saturday.
    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

            Rutte said he told Putin â€œthe opportunity expires to show the world that he is serious about helping.â€
    

            The tributes at the Dutch Embassy in Moscow include a hand-drawn picture of a plane broken in midair with the caption â€œchildren should not die,â€ in a childâ€™s handwriting.
    

            Another message reads: â€œWe are afraid, we are ashamed, we are in mourning.â€  
    

            While the official Russian position is that Russia played no role and has no responsibility for the crash, whatâ€™s striking in many of the notes is the use of the phrase â€œforgive us.â€
    

            The messages give a sense that the people who have left them do feel that Russia has an element of responsibility in what is playing out in eastern Ukraine.
    

            One note reads, in English, â€œExcuse us, please, if you can. Sorry! Russia, Moscow.â€
    

            Paying his condolences at the embassy, Muscovite Yuri Yemshanov told CNN it was â€œdifficult to recognize that our country could be involved in this accident.â€
    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

            â€œI think thereâ€™s lot of proof that weâ€™re in closer relations and connections with the separatists in Ukraine. I suppose itâ€™s clearly understood that we support them by providing weapons, and so I think it doesnâ€™t matter who launched that rocket. Just because weâ€™re supporting terrorists, weâ€™re involved.â€ 
    

            His wife, Marina, added: â€œI think there should be investigation, but of course many things are understood now and we probably could know who did this. Now I think itâ€™s time to say Iâ€™m sorry for these people. This is the  first thing.â€ 
    

            Another woman, who gave her name as Olga, said that she was sure Russia was not involved in the tragedy and that an investigation would establish who was, but she added: â€œHowever, I would also say â€˜forgive me.â€™ Iâ€™m feeling the same.â€
    

            Arnold van Sinderen, a Dutch citizen living in Moscow, told CNN he believed that the West painted the wrong image of Putin, but that all the same, the Russian leader needed to step up.
    

            â€œItâ€™s time to take responsibilities there and bring peace in this region. He should take his responsibility as well with what is happening with the plane crash; this might accelerate the situation.â€
    

            Meantime, the tributes outside the embassy pile up.

heading: Why Russiaâ€™s military adventures worry Europe
article_content:
As Russia flexes its military muscles, Baltic states remain on edge
Trump indicated he may break away from US foreign policy traditions during campaign 
Baltics rely heavily on NATO, US protection from Russia

            Janis Garisons isnâ€™t surprised when he hears allegations of Russian hacks targeting the recent US presidential election.Â 
    

            â€œSome things you discovered in your pre-election campaign, weâ€™ve been seeing it already for years,â€ he says.
    

            â€œTheyâ€™ve been keeping us awake for twenty-five years,â€ he tells CNN. â€œWeâ€™re facing Russian propaganda, information warfare and even psychological warfare almost daily.â€
    

      
      

      

    

            Garisons is a top official in the defense ministry of Latvia, a small Baltic country that was ruled for nearly a half century by the Kremlin.
    

            When asked for a response, Maria Zakharova, spokeswoman for Russian foreign minister told CNN: â€œWhy didnâ€™t Latvia inform Russia about it through the appropriate channels?â€

    

            This year, Latvia celebrated a quarter century of regaining independence after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. But even now, as a part of the European Union as well as a member of the NATO military alliance, the threat from Moscow still lingers. 
    

            Colonel Ilmars Lejins of the Latvian Armed Forces says he considers Latviaâ€™s enormous Russian neighbor his primary threat.
    

            â€œOur neighbor to the East has shown his intents and capability of disrespecting international law and treaty obligations,â€ Lejins says.Â â€œSo I must consider that in my military planning.â€
    

            Tensions in eastern Europe have been ratcheting up ever since Russiaâ€™s annexation of Crimea in 2014, and the US military presence in the region has increased significantly. 
    

            But the election of Donald Trump has thrown the Baltic States, including Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania (who rely heavily on US protection), into a great deal of uncertainty.  
    

      
      

      

    

            During the campaign, Trump outlined a sharp break in US foreign policy tradition, suggesting the 
 including the Baltic states, against Russian aggression if they havenâ€™t â€œfulfilled their obligation to us.â€
    

            This rhetoric, combined with his public admiration for Russian President Vladimir Putin, has left 
that a new Cold War with Putin is coming. 
    

            Publicly, officials in Baltic countries are taking a wait-and-see approach. They stress that they have dramatically increased defense expenditures for the next several years while reminding the US that they have contributed troops to US-led military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.
    

            Former Georgian president Mikheil Saakashvili, who famously fought and lost a war against Russia in 2008, predicts the next several months could be particularly tense. 
    

            â€œBaltic countries are so vulnerable,â€ Saakashvili told CNN from Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, where he is forming a local political party. 
    

            â€œWe see that the military potential of these three countries (Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia) cannot match, in any way, the Russian military. And the problem is: I donâ€™t see large European powers coming to their help.â€
    

            

    

            In a snowy field in Latvia, cannons lob artillery shells at distant targets. A pair of Blackhawk helicopters land, and soldiers from the US Armyâ€™s 173rd Airborne Brigade pour out, firing a rocket attached to a long cord laced with explosives.Â It detonates, a simulation of how soldiers would blow a path through a deadly minefield in the event of a conflict.Â 
    

            US troops are performing military maneuvers with the Latvian military and a platoon of soldiers from Slovenia as part of a series of joint exercises called â€œAtlantic Resolve.â€
    

            â€œThe origins were in response to Russian activity in 2014, when the strategic situation changed,â€ said Colonel Gregory Anderson, who monitored this exercise with his local counterpart Colonel Lejins. 
    

            Anderson was referring to Russiaâ€™s lightning-swift occupation and annexation of the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.
    

            To confuse and then push Ukrainian troops out of the region, Russia deployed so-called â€œlittle green men,â€ well-disciplined Russian forces who wore uniforms without insignia or flags identifying their country of origin.
    

            The well-choreographed operation has served as a wake-up call to the new strength and sophistication of the Russian military.Â 
    

            

    

            If a conflict suddenly exploded with Russia, Latvian commanders say their forces would present little more than a â€œspeed bumpâ€ to an advancing Russian military.
    

            â€œTherefore, the US presence here is very important to deter Russian attempts or simply to avoid miscalculation,â€ says Garisons, Latviaâ€™s secretary of state.
    

            Latvian officials say, Russia has amassed two armies with an estimated 200,000 troops on the other side of the border.Â Five years ago, Russia reestablished a helicopter base with scores of aircraft at a location a short drive from the Latvian border.Â 
    

      
      

      

    

            To protect itself and its population of nearly two million people, Latvia has only 5,000 professional troops as well as a much larger force of volunteer National Guards.
    

            â€œWe need to be a good speed bump that takes out the muffler of the enemy so that it is loud enough that there is no question that this is military aggression against one NATO member,â€ Colonel Lejins explains. â€œThen the activation of (Article 5) occurs.â€
    

            Under Article 5 of the NATO charter, an attack on one member is considered an attack on all countries in the alliance and requires an active response.
    

            Next, we drive cross country from Latvia, across Lithuania and into Kaliningrad, an exclave of Russian territory sandwiched between Poland and the Baltics, cut off from mainland Russia.
    

            At the end of World War II, Soviet Red Army soldiers wrenched control of this territory from Nazi Germany. For decades, it was a heavily militarized region, closed off to foreigners.
    

            The region lurched into the headlines last fall after Russia confirmed reports it deployed nuclear-capable Iskender missiles to Kaliningrad.
    

            Â Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov defended Russiaâ€™s right to deploy weapons to its sovereign territory in an interview with CNNâ€™s Christiane Amanpour last October. 
    

            â€œThey moved NATO infrastructure next to our borders,â€ Lavrov said.Â â€œAnd this is not United States territory.â€
    

            In many ways, Kaliningrad is a historical curiosity. The streets of the main city, which was known in German times as Konigsberg, are lined with grand examples of old German architecture alongside grim, concrete Soviet apartment blocks. 
    

            Here, some Russians also expressed hope about the next US government.Â 
    

            â€œWith the change of leadership in the US we are hoping for an improvement in the situation,â€ says Konstantin Smernov, a 53-year-old former lieutenant in the Soviet Navy who now works as a real estate agent. â€œConfrontation isnâ€™t good for anybody.â€ Â 
    

      
      

      

    

            Western governments imposed economic sanctions on Russia after the seizure of Crimea in 2014. In restaurants and in homes here, many Russians said those measures contributed to a broader economic crisis that set in after the plunge in oil prices in recent years.Â  Oil and natural gas are two of Russiaâ€™s most important exports and the backbone of the countryâ€™s economy.
    

            Those sanctions, combined with a move last summer to remove visa-free travel for Kaliningrad residents traveling to neighboring Poland, have some here concerned about the former Soviet citadelâ€™s increasing isolation.
    

            

    

            Anna Shugatova was born after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Her dream was to find a job that would allow her to travel. But the 23-year-old, who moved to Kaliningrad from her home in Siberia to pursue a masterâ€™s degree in linguistics, says that dream is now in doubt. 
    

            â€œI donâ€™t know if I will be able to travel soon. There are tensions between countries,â€ Shugatova said.
    

            But several Russians say theyâ€™ve found one advantage to living in an enclave with relatively easy access to countries like Poland and Lithuania. Visitors can purchase and smuggle in foreign foods that are now banned in Russia.Â 
    

            â€œWe are back to the days of smuggling cheese and sausage from abroad,â€ said Igor Pleshkov, a businessman and vocal critic of the Kremlin who describes himself as the sole elected member of the opposition on Kaliningradâ€™s city council.
    

            The Russian port of Baltiysk, about a 45-minute drive towards the coast, is still very much a militarized garrison town. Warships from the Russian Navyâ€™s Baltic Sea Fleet moor at the town entrance, while rows of olive-green military trucks and armored vehicles can be seen in several nearby compounds. 
    

            One of the striking oddities about this region is the dozens of ruined German churches dotting the countryside.Â These crumbling places of worship stand partially collapsed and empty, symbols of what happened the last time armies fought for control of this part of Europe.
    

  CNNâ€™s Alla Eshchenko contributed to this report.

heading: Pope Francis gives Christmas message of service to Vatican staff, priests
article_content:
Pope Francis urges the Curia to be professional and to serve the rest of the church
He also warns against gossip, saying it
is harmful to people and the church's work
This is Francis' first Christmas message to the Roman Curia
Since becoming pope, he has been taking steps to reform the way the Holy See is run

            Pope Francis put the ideals of professionalism, service and holiness to the fore Saturday in his first Christmas message to the Curia, the Roman Catholic Churchâ€™s governing body.
    

            The Roman Curia, which includes Vatican staff, priests and cardinals, gathered in the ornate Clementine Hall. The pope praised those who have worked in the Vatican for â€œmany years with immense dedication, hidden from the eyes of the world.â€
    

            The church needs â€œpeople who work with competence, precision and self sacrifice in the fulfillment of their daily duties,â€ he said.
    

            Without professionalism, Francis warned, â€œthere is a slow drift downwards towards mediocrityâ€ and â€œdossiers become full of trite and lifeless informationâ€ that fail to inspire.
    

      
      

      

    

            Without an attitude of service to bishops and churches worldwide, he said, â€œthe structure of the Curia turns into a ponderous, bureaucratic customs house, constantly inspecting and questioning, hindering the working of the Holy Spirit and the growth of Godâ€™s people.â€
    

            Holiness encompasses an openness to God, prayer, deep humility and fraternal charity in relationships with fellow workers, Francis said. 
    

            â€œIt also means apostleship, discreet and faithful pastoral service, zealously carried out in direct contact with Godâ€™s people. For priests, this is indispensable,â€ he said.
    

            He also urged the Curia to avoid indulging in gossip, saying: â€œGossip is harmful to people, our work and our surroundings.â€
    

            Francis has already taken a number of steps to try to reform the Vaticanâ€™s administration in the nine months since he was elected to the papacy.
    

            CNNâ€™s Vatican reporter John Allen, also a senior correspondent for the National Catholic Reporter, said Saturdayâ€™s speech was brief but set out some core principles.
    

            â€œHe said very clearly he wants a Vatican that is focused on service, rather than power,â€ Allen said.
    

            In July, the pope set up an expert committee to recommend reforms to the economic and administrative structures of the Holy See. He has also ordered more scrutiny of the Vatican bank, which has been plagued by financial scandals for years.
    

            Earlier this month, he announced the creation of a commission to prevent the abuse of minors and to support victims of abuse.
    

            The Catholic Church has faced calls for reform in the wake of scandals involving the sexual abuse of children by priests and allegations of corruption.
    

            Since taking charge, Francis has also shifted the tone of the church toward a focus on service, compassion and helping the poor and addressed controversial issues such as homosexuality and the role of women in the church.
    

            At his final general audience of 2013 in St. Peterâ€™s Square on Wednesday, the pope spoke about the birth of Jesus and the importance of humility.
    

            â€œIt is an ugly thing,â€ he said, â€œwhen you see a Christian who doesnâ€™t want to humble himself, who doesnâ€™t want to serve, a Christian who struts about everywhere: itâ€™s ugly, eh? That is not a Christian: thatâ€™s a pagan!â€
    

            In a measure of the impact heâ€™s already had as pontiff, Francis was named as Time magazineâ€™s â€œPerson of the Yearâ€ this month.
    

            The Vatican welcomed Timeâ€™s selection, while making it clear the man so widely recognized for his own humility didnâ€™t seek the award and didnâ€™t want its light to shine on him but on the mission of the church.

heading: Australian Open tennis stars urged not to feed mice in hotel rooms
article_content:
â€œWee, sleekit, cowrin, timâ€™rous beastie,â€ 
 renowned Sottish poet Robert Burns in his poem â€œTo a Mouse.â€
    

            Itâ€™s a sentiment perhaps shared by some 
 stars, who locked in their hotel rooms for two weeks with no human interaction ahead of the 
, appear to be having a fair bit of contact with said timâ€™rous beasties.
    

            Notably world No. 28 Yulia Putintseva, who was forced to swap rooms in her quarantine hotel in Melbourne after she discovered a mouse, only to find out that her new room was also infested.
    

            In a video she posted on Twitter, the Kazakhstan player said: â€œDifferent room same story. Wanted to go to sleep but noooope!â€
    

            

    
itâ€™s actually a lot of them! Not even 1 in my room nowğŸ¤¦ğŸ¼â€â™€ï¸ 

            The 26-year-old followed up with another video saying: â€œItâ€™s actually a lot of them! Not even 1 in my room now.â€
    

            As a strategy to deal with any mice in hotel rooms, Victoriaâ€™s emergency services minister Lisa Neville recommended not feeding them.
    

            â€œAs I understand there may have been some feeding going on,â€ Neville 
 CNN affiliate 9news.
    

            â€œFirstly, we moved the particular tennis player the other day. Weâ€™ve had the hotel pest control this week and I think there may have been some feeding going on with the mice.â€
    

            Putintseva is one of the 72 players and their teams that have been forced to quarantine in their hotel rooms for 14 days after their arrival in Australia ahead of 2021â€™s first grand slam.
    

            

    

            Without the ability to go out and train ahead of the tournament, players have voiced their frustrations, including record eight-time Australian Open menâ€™s singles winner Novak Djokovic, who put forward a list of proposals that would loosen the restrictions on the quarantining stars, including moving players to houses with courts, better food, and reducing the number of days in isolation.
    

            Putintseva herself was one of the first players to complain about the treatment of the players, raising concerns about the lack of fresh air and the fact windows canâ€™t be opened.

heading: (Itâ€™s not just you) Brexit is making Britain very hard to understand right now
article_content:
The UK must look very weird to the outside world at the moment. 
    

            Donâ€™t worry though: Brexit, 
, has left much of the UKâ€™s population just as confused. 
    

            This week, it looked as though Prime Minister Theresa Mayâ€™s hard-won yet widely-loathed Brexit deal with the European Union would finally have its moment in the spotlight, as lawmakers were set to vote in the House of Commons on Tuesday. Then, after a weekend of speculation, 

    

            48 hours later, she 
. The result of this vote â€“ win or lose â€“ could fundamentally alter the Brexit timetable and change the entire complexion of UK politics.  
    

      
      

      

    

            One of the most common questions that European politicos are asked by people with better things to do is â€œwhat will actually happen with Brexit?â€ For the last couple of years, itâ€™s been possible to conjure up half answers that sound a bit clever and move on. But the awful truth, even this late in the game, is that no one knows â€“ even the people in charge. 
    

            This partly stems from the current reality of British politics. No one, it seems, has a workable plan that can be credibly presented as something that might, you know, feasibly happen. 
    

            May and her inner circle have failed to convince the UKâ€™s Parliament that her deal really is the best â€“ and only â€“ thing on the table.
    

            As a result, the Prime Minister pulled the so-called meaningful vote on her Brexit deal, presumably for fear of a heavy defeat and the chain of events that could follow.
    

            Should she survive the confidence vote, May will then head back to Brussels in the hope that she get secure sufficient assurances on her deal and sway MPs to vote for it. 
    

            Never let it be said that the Prime Minister is not an optimistâ€¦
    

            One of the many problems she faces is that even her own Conservative Party hates the deal, in large part because of something called the Irish border backstop. 
    

            The border between the Republic of Ireland (an EU member state) and Northern Ireland (part of the UK) has been the thorniest issue of the whole Brexit process. For historical reasons, both negotiating teams have from day one said that avoiding a hard border was an absolute priority. 
    

            Unfortunately, for boring reasons to do with trade and customs, that is likely impossible unless Northern Ireland is in some kind of Customs Union with the EU, which means the whole UK if you donâ€™t want to break up the Union.
    

            Conservatives loathe this, as they have long hailed the ability to independently trade with countries around the world as the prize for Brexit (see why that is a fantasy 
). 
    

            Then thereâ€™s the opposition Labour Party and its fudgy Brexit policy. Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn seemed to as good as admit on Monday that he accepted the negotiations were closed and that the EU would not budge on the border. He also implied that May should stand aside and allow a leader (presumably one J. Corbyn) capable of negotiating a better deal to take over. It doesnâ€™t take a genius to work out the problem here.  
    

            Labourâ€™s other problem is that it is almost as divided as the Conservative Party on Brexit â€“ especially on the matter of a second referendum, or the Peopleâ€™s Vote, as itâ€™s known. Corbyn and his top team seem reluctant to endorse this outright. They certainly donâ€™t want to be seen as supporting any efforts to prevent Brexit â€“ something many in Westminster believe to be the ultimate intention of the Peopleâ€™s Vote.  
    

            The Peopleâ€™s Vote is backed by people across the political spectrum. And its supporters have extra pep in their step after the European Court of Justice ruled that the UK could hypothetically revoke Article 50, should it want to and with a mountain of caveats.
    

      
      

      

    

            But with only 15 weeks to go until Brexit, itâ€™s not exactly clear how such a vote could even be carried out, which of the two main parties would back what side, how it would be funded, what the question would be, how many answers there would be and what government would legislate for it. 
    

            Meanwhile, back on planet Earth, the EU has said repeatedly that negotiations on the Withdrawal Agreement are not going to be reopened; it is likely not possible to have a second referendum before Brexit Day (ergo, the UK would very much not unilaterally have to ask the EU to extend Article 50); there is no guarantee that the Norway option is something the EU even wants (why would it want the second largest EEA economy unbeholden to EU law?); and, whisper it, but both frontbenches support Brexit and would likely have to were there a second referendum. 
    

            So howâ€™s that for clarity? For some unknown reason, politicians of all factions and levels of seniority have had their ill-considered whims indulged for over two years now. Rather than be forcibly whipped in line and made to confront reality, the UKâ€™s all-consuming political vacuum has created a safe space for a sort of fantasy land.
    

            Meanwhile, with only 15 weeks to go until Brexit day, the world still has no clarity on whatâ€™s about to become of its fifth largest economy. 
    

            It might be funny if it wasnâ€™t so terrifying.

heading: The Wiggles singer Greg Page collapses during Australian bushfires relief concert
article_content:
Greg Page, the original lead singer of the popular Australian childrenâ€™s music group 
, has been rushed to hospital during the bandâ€™s charity concert for 
 relief in Sydney.
    

            CNN affiliate Nine News reported Page collapsed toward the end of the concert.
    

            â€œAt the end of the show this evening there was a medical incident off stage involving Greg Page. Medics were called immediately and he was taken to hospital where he is receiving treatment,â€ The Wiggles wrote on Twitter.
    
Update: At the end of the show this evening there was a medical incident  off stage involving Greg Page. Medics were called immediately and he was taken to hospital where he is receiving treatment. We will provide more information as it comes to hand.

            The Wiggles tweeted late Friday they had visited Page in the hospital. 
    

            â€œHeâ€™s so grateful for the messages of love & support from around the world,â€ the tweet read. â€œGregâ€™s main concern was that the show tonight should go on. Letâ€™s do it for Greg whilst raising much needed funds.â€
    
Weâ€™ve visited Greg this morning & he wanted to thank everyone for their well wishes. Heâ€™s so grateful for the messages of love & support fromâ£ around the world. Gregâ€™s main concern was that the show tonight should go on.â£ Letâ€™s do it for Greg whilst raising much needed funds 

            The band were performing in a sold-out reunion concert in aid of three groups tackling the fires raging through Australia.
    

            Dressing as Blue, Red, Yellow and Purple Wiggles, the band became hugely popular in Australia after they formed in 1991.

heading: NSA leaker Edward Snowden deserves a Nobel Prize, his father says
article_content:
NEW: Edward Snowden has job offers in Russia and has a girlfriend there, lawyer says
Snowden's father says he wants to get on with his life but stresses that he loves his son
Snowden fled the U.S. after leaking information about NSA spy programs 
He received asylum in Russia after being holed up at a Moscow airport for weeks

            The father of NSA leaker 
 told reporters in Moscow that he thinks his son deserves a Nobel Peace Prize.
    

            He arrived there Thursday for his first visit with his son since the former government IT contractor fled the United States after leaking National Security Agency spy program details to the media.
    

            Members of the European Parliament nominated Snowden  in September  for the Andrei Sakharov Prize, which honors figures who stand up to oppressive powers.  The prize was awarded to Pakistani education activist Malala Yousafzai on Thursday.
    

            â€œEdward took the Sakharov prize nomination very calmly,â€ Lon Snowden told reporters at Moscowâ€™s Sheremetyevo International Airport. â€œHe wanted to expose the injustices in the American system, and wasnâ€™t doing it with any awards in mind.â€
    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

      
      

      

    

            Edward Snowden collected information on spy programs, in which the NSA mined phone and Internet metadata from thousands of people inside and outside of the United States. He exposed the program to the media.
    

            Anticipating legal consequences, he initially fled to Hong Kong in late May but flew to Moscow on June 23. He was holed up at the airport for more than five weeks. U.S. authorities have charged him with espionage and theft of government property.
    

            Snowden received asylum in Russia on August 1 and left the airport.
    

            

    

            

    

            Lon Snowdenâ€™s visit to Russia seems shrouded in mystery, as Edward Snowden is keeping information about himself close to the vest.
    

            â€œIâ€™ve had no direct contact with my son despite previous reports, so I really have no idea what his intentions are,â€ Lon Snowden told reporters at the airport.
    

            
 has kept a low profile, apparently not even telling his father where in Russia he is living. 
    

            â€œI cannot answer the question if Edward is in Moscow,â€ Lon Snowden said. â€œI donâ€™t know that. I havenâ€™t been informed where Edward is right now.â€
    

            His lawyer, Anatoly Kucherena, also has not disclosed Snowdenâ€™s location. But he told reporters that he had met with him Wednesday.  
    

            It appears that Snowden is settling in to his new surroundings.
    

            He has been living from savings and donations but has had some job offers, Kucherena said.
    

            â€œI am confident that he would find a high-paying job. He is very capable.â€  He is also learning Russian and soaking in Russian culture, Kucherena said.
    

            And he has a girlfriend.
    

            The lawyer earlier told reporters that Edward Snowden may hold a news conference soon, but later reversed that, saying the former contractor had no intention of speaking publicly.
    

            Since the movie â€œThe Fifth Estateâ€ came out, which is based on the experiences of WikiLeaker Julian Assange, producers have contacted Snowden about telling his story on film. 
    

            But he does not seem interested at the time.
    

            

    

            As in the past, Lon Snowden defended his sonâ€™s actions Thursday, calling him a â€œwhistle-blowerâ€ who is â€œnot leaking information.â€  
    

            â€œI donâ€™t think the American public knows all the details of what my son did,â€ he said.
    

            Snowden has said that he does not expect his son to receive a fair trial in the United States and would not want him to come home, until that changes. 
    

            â€œIâ€™m not sure that my son will be returning to the U.S. again. Thatâ€™s his decision. He is an adult,â€ the elder Snowden told reporters.
    

            He thanked the Russian people and President Vladimir Putin for taking his son in. â€œI consider Edward to be absolutely safe in Russia. He is comfortable here,â€ he said.
    

            Lon Snowden has received a visa for multiple entries into the country.  â€œI hope to return to Russia many times,â€ he said.
    

            Father Lon carefully separated his own interests from Edward Snowdenâ€™s, speaking of getting on with his own life in the United States, while his son moves on with his in Russia.
    

            But he in no way distanced himself from the younger Snowden.
    

            He told reporters: â€œI am his father. I love my son.â€
    

            

    

  CNNâ€™s Boriana Milanova contributed to this report.

heading: Venus Williams exits on rough day for Americans
article_content:
Venus Williams loses to Belinda Bencic 
Williams made last year's final 
Tough day for Americans in Melbourne 
Rafael Nadal crushes Victor Estrella Burgos

            Comebacks were the order of the day at the Australian Open. 
    

            Typically understated in victory, Williams on that occasion dropped her racket, pirouetted and skipped to the net. A double pirouette soon followed and you couldnâ€™t wipe the smile off her face. It set the tone for a fine 2017 season, even if the evergreen Williams lost to younger sister Serena in the final. 
    

            

    

            

    

            But handed with a tough draw at this yearâ€™s Australian Open, the seven-time grand slam champion couldnâ€™t replicate last yearâ€™s success at Melbourne Park and was upset by a resurgent Belinda Bencic 6-3 7-5 on what was a difficult day for Americans on the first day of the yearâ€™s first major. 
    

            â€œThis is, like, a new year,â€ Williams, who was seeking to become the oldest grand slam winner in tennis history, told reporters. â€œYou canâ€™t live in the previous year. Itâ€™s impossible.
    

            â€œI donâ€™t think I played a bad match. She just played above and beyond. I just have to give her credit for that.â€
    

            With Serena skipping the event because the record 23-time grand slam winner isnâ€™t ready to return to tournament play four months after giving birth to a first child, it means no Williams sister is in the second round of a major for the first time since 1997. 
    
âŒ Venus Williams OUT 
âŒ Jack Sock OUT 
âŒ Sloane Stephens OUT
âŒ CoCo Vandeweghe OUT
âŒ John Isner OUT 
A tough day for Americans on the first day of the 
â¡ 
 

            

    

            Joining the 37-year-old Venus in making early exits were Sloane Stephens â€“ who hasnâ€™t won a match since surprisingly 
in September â€“ and Vandeweghe. All three made the semifinals in New York. 
    

            The fourth American semifinalist at Flushing Meadows, Madison Keys, is still in contention â€“ she wonâ€™t contest her opener against Chinaâ€™s Wang Qiang until Tuesday. 
    

            And menâ€™s eighth seed Jack Sock, a semifinalist at the year-end Tour Finals in London in November, tumbled at the hands of Japanâ€™s Yuichi Sugita 6-1 7-6 (7-4) 5-7 6-3. 
    

            Of the 15 Americans on the schedule Monday, only three â€“ Ryan Harrison, qualifier Mackenzie McDonald and Nicole Gibbs â€“ prevailed.
    

            Another player who enjoyed success in New York was also eliminated, menâ€™s finalist Kevin Anderson. The Florida-based South African fell to Kyle Edmund â€“ the lone British man in the draw in the 
 â€“ 6-7 (4-7) 6-3 3-6 6-3 6-4. 
    
When you wake up day one of the 
 and remember you arenâ€™t in the draw ğŸ˜¢ 

            Bencic encountered a Williams sister in the first round for a second consecutive Australian Open â€“ she lost to Serena 12 months ago â€“ but this time around the former prodigy was in much better form. 
    

            Having climbed to seventh in the rankings in 2016, back and wrist injuries heavily contributed to the Swiss dropping to 317th last season. 
    

            Bencic, however, finished 2017 by going 28-3 at all levels and combined with Roger Federer to help Switzerland win this monthâ€™s Hopman Cup. Federerâ€™s parents were in the 20-year-oldâ€™s player box at Rod Laver Arena. 
    

            The Swiss took the final four games of the first set, then rallied from a break down in the second to register a first win over Williams in five attempts. 
    
"I don't think I played a bad match. She just played above and beyond. I just have to give her credit for that."
  - 
 2018 
 
 
 

            â€œIt was amazing, this match,â€ Bencic told reporters. 
    

            â€œI think the level was great. Also she beat me four times before, so I was really happy, took my chance this time.
    

            â€œObviously just happy to be back playing. It was a very, very long time when I was out. I couldnâ€™t wait to come back, so it means a lot.â€
    

            

    

            

    

            Given Bencicâ€™s form, donâ€™t discount a long stay in Melbourne. With Serena out of action â€“ just as she was for the final three majors of 2017 â€“ the womenâ€™s draw is fairly wide open as Vandewegheâ€™s conqueror, Timea Babos, acknowledged. 
    

            â€œIn womenâ€™s tennis, I think we see it â€“ anything can happen when there is no Serena Williams,â€ said the Hungarian, who triumphed 7-6 (7-4) 6-2. 
    

            Vandeweghe received a code violation from chair umpire Fergus Murphy, as she wasnâ€™t ready to take to the court because she was eating a banana. Vandeweghe said she had to wait for the bananas â€“ a good source of potassium â€“ to be brought courtside, hence the delay. 
    

            Stephens was ruled out of this monthâ€™s Brisbane International with a knee injury and lost in straight sets to Camila Giorgi in the first round in Sydney, hardly the best preparation for Melbourne. 
    

            Not serving out the match at 5-4 in the second set Monday was the obvious turning point and the 13th seed went out to Chinaâ€™s Zhang Shuai â€“ somewhat of a fan favorite at the Australian Open â€“ 2-6 7-6 (7-2) 6-2 to suffer an eighth straight defeat. 
    

            â€œI did everything that I could to be ready for Sydney last week and for here,â€ Stephens told reporters. â€œItâ€™s just unfortunate, but itâ€™s definitely only the beginning of the season, first two tournaments. Not going to get too down.â€
    

            Zhang was close to quitting tennis following an 0-for-14 skid at grand slams. Her fortunes changed, though, when she upset Simona Halep in the first round in Melbourne two years ago and last week she narrowly missed out on a seeding for Melbourne, coming in ranked 34th. 
    

            Rafael Nadal progressed to the second round in 94 minutes, downing 37-year-old Victor Estrella Burgos 6-1 6-1 6-1. It was a flawless start from  the world No. 1, who is playing the Australian Open for the first time without competing at a warmup tournament. Blame his knees. 
    

            

    

            Nadal drew as much attention for his attire, going back to a sleeveless look for the first time in nearly a decade. 
    

            The man Nadal lost to in last yearâ€™s gripping menâ€™s finale, Federer, begins his quest for a 20th major Tuesday against Sloveniaâ€™s Aljaz Bedene. 
    

            Six-time Australian Open champion Novak Djokovic, meanwhile, plays his first official match since Wimbledon against Donald Young. 
    

            If Young topples Djokovic, it would no doubt bring some joy to American tennis in Melbourne following Mondayâ€™s dreadful start.

heading: Mo Salahâ€™s â€˜killing of innocent peopleâ€™ tweet prompts comments on what he doesnâ€™t say

            In a widely shared Twitter post, Liverpool and Egypt star Mo Salah urged world leaders, specifically British Minister Boris Johnson, â€œto do everything in their power to make sure the violence and killing of innocent people stops immediately.â€
    
Iâ€™m calling on all the world leaders including on the Prime Minister of the country that has been my home for the past 4 years to do everything in their power to make sure the violence and killing of innocent people stops immediately. Enough is enough.  

            But the post generated as much comment for what it didnâ€™t say, as for what it did.

            Author Samar Jarrah tweeted: â€œHope next tweet you will mention Palestinians.â€
